description:
I love finding somewhat hidden spots in cities that I visit. On a recent trip to San Francisco, I came across this lovely restaurant. It was lunch time on a weekday. There were barely any people in the restaurant, and I was able to get a great spot by the window. 

I loved the relaxed ambiance and friendly staff. They seemed totally fine with my hanging out to use the wifi. I am a slow eater, so this was a nice added bonus to be able to get some work done during lunch, especially since not all spots in San Francisco seem to have free WiFi. 

I ordered a glass of their house wine, a bowl of lentil soup and the yogurt cucumber dip. This is a typical mean for me at any Persian restaurant. I really wanted to try their dolmas but they were out. The lentil soup was filling, but maybe could have used a little bit more flavor. The wine and dip were both refreshing, and I didn't feel like I overate. 

I am curious about those dolmas! They also had some other dishes that I wish I had been hungry enough to try. Next time!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
It was my first time trying this restaurant..and obviously the last!! It was a delivery order by the way.
First of all the food came in really late. I always keep tracking the driver when i order for delivery (and the driver left the restaurant very late). And the most important, that i found haor in the food, not just in one plate, but in both pates i ordered!!! I felt they doing it in purpose.
When i called asking for explanation, the lady on the phone was super rude, and ended up by hanging up on my face!!
I will never recommend this place to someone!!
author: Bilel K.

description:
Wanted to place an order for pickup a couple times. The woman who answered the phone was very rude. I asked her to give me a second, while I made sure I ordered the right thing, and she hung up on me. Twice
The first time, I was never told that I wasn't being heard correctly. The call ended. The second time, I asked to be given a bit of time, and the call ended a few seconds later. The host made me feel very rushed. I understand restaurants are busy, and time is money, but I also would have appreciated some patience from them since I wanted my order to be correct, and I feel like asking for a few seconds is not asking for a lot. 
It also happened to my husband when he called a while later. We were trying to keep an open mind. Again, he had trouble reading a menu item, and had a few seconds of silence to try to rehearse the word, and the call ended. It couldn't have been both my phone and his phone with that problem. We had full WiFi and good connection. All of our other calls came in just fine. It seemed more like a lack of patience than a misunderstanding.
Perhaps the restaurant's phone is having issues, in which case, I would hope it gets upgraded to a better phone that doesn't hang up on people. For customers that are not walking into your restaurant, the impression they get about the business is through their interaction over the phone.
author: Monica M.

description:
Had dinner here the other day with a large group and had a great experience.

We had a reservation and were seated and served pretty promptly. I had the barg skewers (beef), but it seemed like most of the skewers and stews were all great.

It was a bit pricey for the food, but I'd definitely come back here if someone was craving persian food for a special occasion.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I have kind of mixed feelings about Anar.

We came here on a Friday night (reservation for 730PM) and service was pretty slow considering there was only one larger party of 10 people and another couple in the restaurant. There were several open tables.

I ordered the joojeh kebab (boneless) with salad as the side and while it was good, I think $17 is a little overpriced. I don't mean that it wasn't enjoyable just that for the ambiance, service, and very plain salad, $17 seemed a bit much.

The tahdig was SO crispy it was almost impossible to eat. It was really, really crunchy. 

I don't think this would be my first choice for a Friday night but I'll probably return to try another menu item and order a more interesting side.
author: Sarah L.

description: The food is delicious, and the staff is very friendly! Try the Fesenjan; it's not very often that Persian restaurants offer it, plus they did a great job in making what is a difficult meal to prepare! Also the restaurant is great for a quieter atmosphere, making it great as a friend or date night spot.
author: Cameron K.

description:
If I could give this place ten stars, I really would.

The venue is quiet and cozy with ambient lighting and music. The service was excellent, we were always greeted with smiles and our waitress even offered to charge our phones for us.

The food was authentic and delicious, with carefully-spiced entrees and a delicious desserts. We tried a stew and some grilled meat skewers, as you will see in our photos. 

I would highly recommend the The restaurant to anybody who enjoys authentic Persian food with professional and courteous service.
author: Herb Q.

description:
Were visiting San Francisco from LA and had a sudden craving for some hot comforting Persian food! Checked yelp and saw that Anar had a great rating and decided to give it a try. Glad we did!

we ordered the tadig with gheymeh and fesenjoon stews. although the portion of the stews were a bit small for stews were packed with so much flavor and really hit the spot on that cold night

we also ordered a soltani plate with white rice - very good

thought the restaurant was in a random part of town - not many things around it but I would definitely recommend to any locals looking for a traditional authentic Persian meal
author: Dani F.

description: The food is excellent!  The service is exemplary!  The prices are reasonable!  Winner, winner, Persian dinner!
author: David C.

description:
I've been there couple days ago , and I would say thats the real deal in terms of the quality of the food and service! omg I finally found a spot with a truly Persian food , in this place quality contained in everything , the service is amazing! super friendly , and the most its not expensive !!! thats why I would suggest make a reservation if you don't wanna wait in the line ! great place to celebrate something with your friends ! 
def should try ice cream ! thats bomb ! just wanted to say thank you guys you're amazing! keep going in that direction! see you soon!
author: Johny D.

description: First time trying Persian food. A Persian friend recommended this place. I would say this is a very positive introduction. It's very clean and has pretty nice decor. I got the lamb kebab. I was surprised that the lamb seemed to be reconstructed ground lamb, not my fav texture but quite tasty. The butter rice was a hit! We ordered more to share.
author: Iris H.

description:
The food is awesome! 
We tried Pomegranate soup!!! (Ashe-e-Anar), Gheymeh Bademjan (something with lamb) and ice cream! 
Very nice.
author: Oksana K.

description:
Rare neighborhood Persian find with friendly service and delicious food at reasonable prices.

I highly recommend the roasted eggplant appetizer, Kashke Bademjan - really delicious and satisfying.  The hummus was good, but not amazing - definitely ask for the house hot sauce, which is delicious.  I love the stews, which are more of a curry consistency, not too watery.  The Fesenjan is their signature dish - "chicken with ground walnut cooked in sour-sweet pomegranate sauce served with rice."  I liked it and definitely recommend trying once, but it was a bit too sweet for my personal taste.  

I've never been here when it's crowded - not sure why, but it's nice to be able to walk in on a Friday at 8pm without reservations. Service has always been friendly.  Atmosphere is fine, not particularly fancy or unique, just a standard restaurant vibe.  I'd love to see them decorate a bit more with Persian decor, maybe some light music in the background, to help set the vibe.
author: Greg B.

description: Absolutely amazing Persian food in a clean cozy environment. Definitely try the sonnati ice cream, it's by far the best persian ice cream I've ever had.
author: Donya F.

description:
I'm persian and I have tried all the persian restaurants around here. Anar is my favorite so far! Everything is really delicious and tasty. You feel like home!
I tried "Baghali polo & lamb shank" and I loved it! Everything is like homemade food and reminds you of Iran! Thank you for the good service and great food!
author: Sara S.

description:
Mediocre food and absolutely awful customer service.

Scene: A group of 6 coworkers plus myself went to Anar for lunch today. Our group was the majority of their Friday lunch crowd, except for a group of 2 and a solo guy.

Situation: I am allergic to bread/gluten. When the waitress took my order for a Kabob Soltani I specifically asked, "Does this come on bread? I can't eat bread". She replied that they could swap the rice for salad, do 50/50 rice/salad, etc. I ordered the kabob w/rice.

Some time later, the Kabob Soltani came out on a bed of lavash bread. I brought this up to the waitress and she claimed that I'd never said anything about my allergy. My coworkers and I were adamant that I had in fact asked for "no bread".

THEIR RESPONSE: Here's the thing - Mistakes happen. As someone with a food allergy, I've been in situations where I have forgotten to mention my intolerance. I've also been in situations like today where the restaurant messed up. It's fine. I'm used to it. What's telling is how the restaurant staff handles the situation. 

The way it was handled by the waitress and manager is that they falsely and repeatedly accused me of not mentioning the bread allergy. Additionally, they said that I could either eat the kabob as-is, or I could pay for a new plate. Why would I eat the kabob that's been laying in bread if I am allergic to bread? Why would I pay for a second plate? In the 7 years that I've been intolerant of bread, this is the first time that a restaurant has asked me to pay to re-make the food -- even counting times where it was my own fault!!

What really topped this off was the awful attitude of the staff. From that moment till we left, they were really bitchy towards us. No politeness. No hospitality. No thank you or goodbyes. Just dirty looks and sh|%%y attitude.


Other feedback on the food: 
* The tadig appetizer was a "D". Not very crispy or crunchy.
* The khoreshts for the tadig (ghormeh sabzee and ghaymeh) were both so-so.
* When the Mirza Ghasemi appetizer came out, one of my coworkers joked that it was mostly tomato paste with a touch of eggplant. Subpar.


Between the mediocre food and the awful customer service, I am never going back here and I would not be surprised if this place is closed within a year. Go at your own peril.
author: Denzel R.

description: Food is tasty! However, the prices are too high. I've been to many other Persian restaurants and I have never had to pay $18 for koobideh with rice and salad. In short, happy with the food; not happy with the price.
author: Jasmine N.

description:
Wow
Never had such a bad experience in my life 

This place is an absolute joke.  Horrible customer service.  Staff that handles business in a 'rude' manner. Why would anyone come back? 

Guys please hire staff that is a little more pleasant, a little more courteous and a little more customer service oriented. 

Based on the rest of the reviews here, you have a problem that obviously isn't being addressed. 

How is it possible that in SF where pretty much everyone checks out reviews these guys don't get the message?! Lol 

Reality check! Take a hint.
author: fahad u.

description:
It is a small place, but with friendly staff - I think it is a family owned resturant.

Their portian size is plenty for one individual. Their koobideh kabob looks different compared to what we are used to see, it is a more yellowish. But It is tasty and juicy. It comes with salad, but unfortunately I was expecting shirazi salad but it is a lettuce with balsamic dressing.

Overall, it is a nice place I would go there again, and check out other entree's.
author: Naser A.

description:
Probably the worst experience I have ever had. I called to place an order for pick up. The lady on the phone said sorry kitchen is closed, I told her that it's 9pm, and I have never heard of a restaurant closing at 9pm on a Friday. She literally says "well whatever you like" and hangs up on me. 

Are you freaking kidding me? ? She must be a very uneducated woman to say something like that. And for a restaurant to close that early during the weekend is absurd. 

Well it's safe to say I will never be ordering food from a place that hires such rude employees who have no manners!

Also check out their reviews, and you'll start to see a pattern. A lot of people are saying that service was bad, they were racist weren't polite to guests. 

Update:- 
I called to speak with the manager and explain to him that the lady i spoke with on the phone was extremely rude and was showing attitude and hung up on me, his reply was, it's my restaurant, I can do whatever I want and hangs up on me again. 

All I can say is WOW!!!  Definitely the place to go if you want to be treated like s***
author: Shanzay H.

description:
best persian food in the bay area and sf.  i really can recommand
great food and friendly service in a iranian  modern ambience
author: Shagha H.

description:
I live around the corner and come here for their lamb shank when I am too lazy to slow cook my own for 6 hours. The meat is well seasoned and oh so tender that it just falls off the bones when you touch it. Mhmmmm...
The rice that the lamb is served on though, is quite dry and bland. I think it actually takes points off of the meat. Since I like to eat meat with carbs like a real woman, Anar, please treat carbs with respect, not an afterthought. Thanks!
I also have tried pretty much all of their appetizers. They are definitely house made and fresh, thought nothing special. The entrees are of good portions, you won't need it anyway.

Recommendations: order a lamb shank, skip appetizers
author: Tata X.

description:
We came here last night with our Persian friend. It didn't disappoint.  His aunt took him here a few times and he said it's probably the most authentic Persian food in the city.  We love it. 

We first started with glasses of wine.  They gave us free samples to decide which wine and then a very heavy pour.  A great start.  ;-).  We did family style

My favorites were the following.  5 stars 
- Anar salad.  Fresh and delicious.   I got it light on the dressing which was perfect.  Loved the combo of broccoli and walnut with the red lettuce 
- ground lamb - omg this was so delicious.  We had to order a second one.   This is probably my favorite kebab of all time. So tender and flavorful but not greasy at all
- half and Half dessert.  The ice cream and vermicelli in rose water.  It's the last one on the dessert menu.  Omg.  I must come back for that and I am not even a dessert person. 

The other stuff we ordered were just okay. I wasn't big fans of the crispy rice appetizer. It seems stale to me.  The stew were authentic according to our friend but an acquired taste. We had the chicken and beef.  Both were unique both not my favorite. 

Overall, a great experience in an unexpected part of town.  We drive by all the time and never noticed this restaurant. We will be back and with friends. ;-)
author: Lei H.

description:
We went to this restaurant twice during my visit to San Francisco because it was in our walking distance and our only Persian restaurant choice considering our limited lunch time. We tried their Koobideh, Barg, and Jooje. Their Koobide was one of  the worst kebab I have ever had. Their Jooje was very salty in a level that made it difficult to enjoy the food. The server was kind at first but things changed when we found a coca in my bag and pour in our glass. They came to us impolite and rude and told us that you must  buy your drink from us. Everybody knows it's better to do that, but mentioning this in front of other customers, in a rude way, is not OK. We even gave them our feedback about the level of salt and instead of respecting our comment they said: "Everyone else enjoys our food"! 
I would never ever go this place again. They must really work on their food and behavior.
author: Hassan N.

description: THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!!  Three of us showed up for dinner on Friday night.  The parking was super easy.  The atmosphere was warm and lovely, and the two waitstaff gracious and accommodating, serving us saffron-sugar sticks and tea while we were waiting for our table.  Most importantly:  The food was absolutely delicious.  We ordered only vegetarian dishes and there was PLENTY of options, especially among the family-style appetizers.  This is one of the most delicious dinners we've had in San Francisco.
author: Alex R.

description:
I haven't had much Persian food so can't attest to the authenticity, but when I do it jives with my low carb diet provided you skip the bread. It's great to have more dining options in an otherwise spartan scene in SOMA. I tagged along as part of a celebratory work dinner. It was all quite tasty, and I was satisfied. Kebabs were better than average and reasonable price. Restaurant space is small, but surprisingly packed a lot of people and comfortable seats and benches.

Lamb chops - My favorite dish of the night, succulent
Lamb koobideh - Having only had beef koobideh, this was flavorful, fatty and not tough like most lamb kebabs.
Ash-e-anar - Thick, sweet and savory pomegranate lentil dip
Jooje kabab (Chicken) - Pieces of chicken breast with veggies, juicy but rather chalky in texture. Seasoned with a lot of lime and a hint of saffron.
author: Truc N.

description:
Small restaurant with Very friendly staff. Nice environment and good vibe.

I didn't like the koobideh and chicken Kabab though, the meat was either not fresh or with too much fat.

They were also out of barg kabab since they were busy. Understandable but not a good excuse for a restaurant.
author: Ramin Y.

description:
Anar has a soothing atmosphere, enriched with the ancient culture of Iran and nice and welcoming staff. I've had many dishes from this place and as a classic Persian, I guarantee it tastes original  The food tastes delicious and detailed with a lot of care.
One time I went there to order food for 7 people and I was taken cared of amazingly. The ladies welcomed me with traditional beverage (ghand pahloo chai ) in my waiting time. I had it while listening to an old Persian movie soundtrack (maadar). It shortly journeyed me to my past. True story ... 100% Iranian approved.
author: Ali Y.

description:
It was moderate. The Barg kabob was good and the Koobideh was ful of fat and the Jooje was somehow dry.
The personnel were great and kind and friendly and extra polite

Most iranian restaurants in this area have free apetizers such as cheese and bried and greens but they dont have such things.
author: Negar A.

description: Friendly service and some excellent items. I loved the dolmes -- very different from the Greek version, and a sweet-savory-sour powerhouse of deliciousness. I also loved the fesenjan, a stew of pomegranite-walnut sauce with chicken. The other items we ordered were good but nothing particularly special. The hummus, for example, was served plainly with lavash bread (no other vegetable garnish) and might have benefited from a little more olive oil in the mix. I tasted my nephew's entree, the lamb and eggplant stew, but it was so different from the fesenjan that I didn't really want to take it in.
author: Alissa F.

description: This restaurant is better than I expected! Nice ambience, very friendly staff, and very good food! I had the Baghali Polo. The lamb shank was well made and the sauce was really good! What really impressed me is their Bastani, a kind of Persian ice cream. The taste of the ice was really refreshing. It's one of my favorite restaurants in SF!
author: Vincent T.

description:
Super delicious food that I've never tried before. 
The flavors are so good. The jeweled rice is amazing. Must try!!
author: M J.

description: Amazing food! We had the fesonjoon and gheymeh bademjan, very large portions, tender chicken and lamb. The chicken/meats are so tender, they fall apart as you pick it up -phenomenal! Also, tried the tea: cardomem with side of cube sugar and raw brown sugar stick. Overall, great service, amazing food, will definitely be coming back!
author: Taj T.

description:
Delicious!  Taste like homemade comfort food.   I had the lamb shank with lentil beans.  
Super friendly waitress.  The food did take a little long but well worth the wait.  Would definitely come more often if I didn't live in SJ.
author: Devin N.

description: This place is spectacular! I took a picture midway through meal because forget that, you'll want to hurry up and dive in to your food. Had quite the spread first time here. I live out of town but it's worth a drive to wherever you live. The staff was excellent, and the restaurant has some nice art for sale. The food itself is art and tastes incredible.
author: Rosebud F.

description: One of my favorites, great food, amazing service. I took one of my American friends to try Persian foods for first time and she said it's amazing! I'll be back soon! I encourage everyone to try this restaurant!
author: Ni M.

description:
I order persian food from Postmates from time to time. Postmates used to offer Maykadeh (another local persian restaurant) which was great! They no longer offer Maykadeh so I decided to try the other option- Anar

To say that I was disappointed is an understatement. I am persian American and this had to be the worst persian food I have ever had. I ordered the Koobideh Kabob and could only eat the rice because the Kabob tasted SO BAD. 

Do not order from here.
author: C S.

description: A solid bet for SoMa Persian/Middle Eastern. Definitely try the kashk-e-bademjan, a perfect eggplant starter that even haters of eggplant will love. Also be sure to try the fesenjan, which you might not find elsewhere. It is a lovely stew of chicken in pomegranate and walnuts. The recipe has got to be as old as the gods, themselves. Always try a Shirazi salad and and ash soup, well it's not really a soup, not really a stew, but somewhere in between. If there are more folks, you can supplement with a ground beef or lamb kebab and some crispy tahdig rice. The option go on and on so you may need to return a couple of times.
author: Brian J.

description:
Hi cleaning it's my first priority,,
I got there and there is a couple ladies they were making salad ,And charging customer in the cash register  with touching the money in the same time plus the bathroom was miserable,,
So I just got a lemonade and I left I didn't even drink it ,
One of the ladies he was fighting with one of the customers he was complaining about one of the dishes was so cold and she did not even look at his face or ask she will take care of it,, I was laughing so hard because the other lady she was watching her phone and the gentleman in the kitchen watching his laptop like nothing happened,,
If the owner of this business he went to close for bankruptcy it's going to be fastest way just make his employee continuing what they doing to the customer,,
author: Ryan B.

description:
One of the best Persian restaurant in San Francisco if not the best. Food is always very generously served and is tasty. Prices are reasonable for San Francisco as well.

We ordered the Kebabs (Koubideh, Chicken, Barg) and they were all good. Their appetizer selection is good as well. We had the kashkeh bademjan and the most-o khiar. All were very well presented.

The only drawback and the reason behind my 4-stars review is the location. It's not a prime one and despite being clean inside, the place lacks a cozy atmosphere to have dinner compared to what San Francisco's restaurants are offering. It still doesn't hold back to the quality of this restaurant and the people behind it.

I'll come back for sure.
author: Shay R.

description:
The service is great and very friendly and the food is absolutely delicious! 
I'm a big fan of the lamb and eggplant dish that is so tender and flavorful.
It's a neighborhood bright spot and I'll be a regular.
author: Jake E.

description: Best Persian food restaurant in San Francisco! Outstanding and cozy. A great example of a family-owned business where the service and care come through.
author: S. N.

description: Intimate, delicious, reasonably-priced home-made style food in a "hidden" part of town. The upside of the non-obvious location is that parking is relatively easy. Most importantly? The lovely family runs the business adding to the cozy feeling of eating grandma's cooking in a living room. Yes, please!
author: Nena G.

description:
Good Persian food (I went with a Persian friend so she knows her stuff!). Not the best in the city, but for the convenience (no wait, slightly easier parking), it's worth checking out.

THE WAIT
None for four of us on a Sunday around 7pm.

THE SERVICE
Professional. A little slow to refill our water.

THE COST
$115.28 before tip for dinner for four.

APPETIZERS
* Kashk-e Bademjam (seasoned roasted eggplant. $8) - 3 stars
A good appetizer if you're hungry, not a major standout.

MAIN COURSES
* Fesenjan (chicken w/ ground walnut, pomegranate sauce. $21) - 3.5 stars
Good dish. The chicken could be more tender. The sauce has a slightly dry aftertaste.

* Ghorme Sabzi (sautéed parsley, green onion, spinach w/ beef. $19) - 3 stars
This had beans which were overwhelming & starchy. I didn't love the sauce. 

DESSERT
* Bastani (ice cream w/ saffron, rose water, pistachio. $6) - 3.5 stars
Rich ice cream, good flavor.

* Faloodeh (rose water infused sherbet w/ rice noodles. $6) - 3 stars
Interesting & unique dessert, but the flavor was too sweet.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Its a very stylish cozy restaurant, we ordered one portion of vaziri and one soltani kabob. The food taste is great, staff are friendly and it is easy to find a parking near the restaurant
Keep up the good work anar staff.  We will definitely come back.
author: Fedi S.

description:
You can find tasty Persian food here, excellent quality ,friendly customer service. It worth to try it once and you'll be a repeat customer.
I 'll definitely try it again in my short stay in SF.
author: AmirHossein K.

description: Nice and good food but very bad service . The couple ladies Were so rude to us and even we asked for water they didn't bring it but the food is so delicious without the couple ladies
author: Abo A.

description:
I am going to make it short and sweet. I have tried most of the Persian restaurants in the bay. Anar has been by far one of the best. It's a family run business and you can feel the love in their food. 
Thanks for such a good experience.
author: Reza S.

description:
The joojeh kebab is the best food on earth. This family-run restaurant has delicious food, attentive and friendly service, and quiet atmosphere with cozy lighting. 

A good selection of both meat and vegetarian options.
author: katie s.

description:
Came in last night for dinner around 7:30. There were no other diners in the restaurant. Although weirded out by the fact that there was not one other customer there on a Friday night, my date and I decided to stay. 

We were greeted and seated by a seemingly friendly woman, given menus and left at our table. We waited about 5 minutes and no one came up to us. At this point there were 3 female employees chatting in the back and a man, presumably one of the workers/owners, on his laptop at a table by the kitchen. We waited several more minutes, looking at the servers, though not attempting to get their attention explicitly, because, as you can tell, it was a weird situation. Another man came out of the kitchen to talk to the others but ignored us as well. 

After almost 10 mins of not being greeted in a completely EMPTY restaurant with 5 capable staff hanging around, we decided to leave. 

We said "sorry we're gonna go" as we walked out the door and although having a slightly concerned look on all their faces, no one said a word to us. Strangest dining experience ever. As a Persian, I was excited to find another Persian restaurant in the city, but what a disappointment... and terrible customer service! No wonder they had no customers on a weekend night.
author: Sam K.

description: Anar? More like An (Farsi for poop). No complimentary feta and bread, koobedieh had lamb and beef when it's traditionally only beef. The tahdegh was not crispy, tasted like it was four hours old. However, the Chicken kabob was very well seasoned but left on the grill a few minutes too long so it tasted dry. Much of the eggplant dishes were too salty. Good if you haven't had Persian food before but does not represent Iranian cuisine accurately
author: Daniel A.

description:
Worst service ever we received.
Never had such a bad experience at a Persian restaurant.
The owner is so unprofessional and not service friendly.
The food is great and presented very nicely, so my compliment to the chef.
author: Afshan L.

description: First time here but will never return If you want to have dog food they have it. The food here is horrible so are the people who work here. The place smells really bad. At some point during our visit the server started yelling at us. I am from LA I know what persian food is and I can guarantee you what they serve its not persian food.  WILL NEVER RETURN AND THE CITY SHOULD RECONSIDER REGRADING THIS PLACE.
author: Biatris S.

description: Personally, I am in love with Pomegranates. They have friendly professional staff and the atmosphere and the interior design is pleasant. The food is a little pricy, but the quality is great.
author: Mehdi S.

description:
There is saying " if you don't have anything nice to say about someone or something don't say anything at all". Unfortunately this one is an expectation.
I believe the restaurant has a lot of potential, but it needs lots of care and attention to details. 
1- Service  is not horrible but can get better. 
2- food is not bad but it needs to get better.
3- the decor definitely needs work. 
Overall, these are just some friendly criticism.
I love to see this business success
In near future.
author: Ali K.

description:
I must agree with most of the comments here. The food is decent but the service can use some help. When we first came in, I wanted to sit at a different table than the one we were guided to and that seemed to really frustrate our waitress who gave me a lot of attitude because of my request. I considered leaving, but did not want to make a scene. 

AMbiancecwise, not exactly a romantic or a date place and the décor could use help. More like a family restaurant.
author: Niloufar M.

description: I came by for lunch on a weekday. They open at noon, but there is no wait, as there isn't much of a lunch crowd. Service is friendly and unobtrusive. We had water brought to our table immediately, and the menus are already there. No complimentary bread or dip, but that's okay because I never know what to do with the raw onion and lavash and butter anyway. I went with my usual kebab koobideh and was not disappointed. It came with a large side of rice, but you can also get half rice/half salad. I really enjoyed how flavorful and juicy my kebabs were, and as usual, I had enough leftover food for lunch the next day. It's not cheap at $17, but the quality and service are good. It's too bad that they're located in such a weird, industrial (think auto repair shops) part of Soma. Otherwise, I'm sure they'd get much more foot traffic.
author: Leslie H.

description: I really liked the Soltani kabob and basmati rice here. They also have wonderful chai although it's a little silly that they charge by the tiny teacup. The ghormeh sabzi and tahdig and the Kookoo was also very good. wait staff was kind but not very attentive which is the reason I took off one star. Would definitely go again
author: Amelie B.

description:
Ordered lamb and chicken kabobs with salad and crispy rice. Very disappointed.  The lamb looked and tasted like prepacked frozen patties rather than freshly made...dry and tastless. The crispy rice was so hard, I couldn't eat it. My bf didn't like the chicken either.

I've had so many great Persian meals in the East Bay and the peninsula, I was really hoping we could find just one decent Persian restaurant in the City.... the search goes on.
author: Cindy W.

description: Very delicious kebabs, friendly and artistic environment, Heli waited on us she was nice and kind, be back again, we're from Nevada.
author: Arsalan T.

description:
This place rocks. 

The pros: 
Fresh and delicious persian food
Friendly and warm service
Comfortable interior 

My wife and I will be back.
author: Marcus L.

description:
We ordered Fesenjoon and chicken kebab with bone-in. Fesenjoon was very tasty and flavorful. On the other hand chicken kebab was very, very dry with no flavor and very hard to chew. Our waitress was lovely and helpful. 
I will give Anar another chance.
author: Simin M.

description: Don't really understand why we got attitude from the staff when we just courteously asked for the corner table that had the requisite amount of space available for our party of 5. We got weird excuses too, like there weren't enough plates to go around? I'm sorry for trying to make it to work for you, lady, but you didn't have to be so rude about it.
author: Jacky C.

description:
This has been the WORST Persian dining experience I've ever had.  Anyone who considers trying this establishment should be warned that their service not typical of a Persian restaurant. 

The owners are completely unprofessional and they didn't want to serve us,  a group of 9 mind you,  tea and pastries at the end of the meal.  This is UNHEARD of in Persian culture.  

This family owned business needs a lot of change in order to survive in San Francisco.  

I will never come back here.  Disgrace to our culture.
author: Reza O.

description:
This place became one of my favorite Kabab house places in town. The food is really good.
I recommend Zavari kabab.

Tonight my wife and I went to this place for dinner. When coming out we forgot to pickup the left over box of our Ghorme Sabzi and I left my Card on the table. I had two waitress running towards us to our car bringing the box and the card and both had smile on their face.

Staff are very friendly and make sure the customers are good taken care of.
author: Hakim A.

description:
- Best way to put it "passive aggressive" attitude from both the server and owner of the place.  I'll make this quick ..

1. - Food was ok.  The Fesenjoon was great.  The rice for the kabob was luke warm and the Dough was extremely thick we needed to add water to make it enjoyable. 

2. Service was not good.  The server never checked up on us to see how we are doing and if we need anything else...  She only "checked up on us" when we had to flag her down to come and attend to us.  I don't consider this as attentive service. 

3. Management was very unprofessional.  She had a very passive aggressive attitude toward us/ her customers.

Example: The bill was dropped at our table without any notification.  We were about to finish our main course and I asked her for the dessert menu and she told us kitchen is closed.  Mind you we went in for a late lunch with a advance notice to them.  When we tried to give her our feedback that NO ONE came to let us know the kitchen is closing or if we needed anything  else before the check was dropped off she smirked and said if would have made no difference since they are closing in a few minutes.  

The net of it is that they rather wanted to peck a fight than to see their customers happy.  

Will not be going back to this place.
author: Ali O.

description: It's hard finding good Persian (Iranian) food in San Francisco esp with great service. We ordered the Ash Anar (pomegrant soup) which was really one of the best i've ever had, kooko sabzi and joojeh. All was very good.
author: Yas G.

description:
I love a good persian food and when I go to a persian restaurant I like to feel like I'm in a restaurant back home. The anar restaurant atmosphere is very chill and nice. We came right after the opened for dinner so it wasn't really busy. 
I ordered the good old soltani kabob which is a combo of barg (filet)and koubideh(ground beef) and my friends got koubideh. As a Persian I can say the koubideh was spot on. Fresh and juicy. However the barg was just ok and for the price it was not really worth it. I would definitely come back again for koubideh only.
Also another thing I'd suggest is that every persian restaurant I go to they always bring bread, cheese, butter and some vegies free of charge and it'd be a nice thing to eat till the food arrives. 
Overall, we had a good experience and I recommend them. I also belive theu deliver.
author: Kourosh F.

description: Anar has probably the worst customer service I have ever experienced. The two waitresses are unbelievably rude and unprofessional. The dishes and chai were slammed in front of us after we asked them to clean the table, where the waitresses left dirty dishes for 30 minutes in front of us. Both need a complete attitude make over if they want to work in the food industry. The food itself was not bad. But the night was ruined by the rude and hostile behavior of the staff. I would not ever recommend this place.
author: Sara S.

description: One of the best Persian foods I've ever had! Very nice atmosphere, attentive servers and perfect service! I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Shaida S.

description:
I had a wonderful joojeh kebab with half rice and half salad. Chicken super buttery and moist, rice full of flavor. But the superstar was the hummus, made with lime. Unreal. Thick and heavy with tahini, so simultaneously hearty and creamy. I wish they offered a side sizing of hummus, i.e. as one of the choices for salad/rice/lavash. 

However, it did take about 30 minutes to get to me at 1pm on a weekday, with only two other tables. That might be related to what I ordered, though I wish I had gotten the hummus sooner (though that was my fault, I told them I wanted them at the same time). I really wanted to dock this place a star for slow service, but I can't do that--the food was so excellent.
author: Gina C.

description:
The food was good , they have very bad attitude
There is two girls didn't like what they do I was eating and I didn't feel good because they were so rude no smile and they make you feel like you want to go fast.Plus when I told him that's not acceptable D said it's up to you if you cannot come again so I did not have the owner of the business knows about that are this is the restaurant policy
author: Hassdo R.

description:
One of the best chicken kebab I've ever had. With bones, the chicken was incredibly flavorful and yet very moist. There is a lot of rice if you just get that and I recommend getting combo side instead.

Lamb stew is also excellent. The eggplant is wonderful in it.

Overall good value and a nice casual sit down dinner. ~$20 a person for hearty entree is hard to come by these days.
author: Victor W.

description: This is the best and most underrated Persian restaurant in bay area. Food is great. Staff are friendly. Parking is easy
author: Hassan G.

description: Mediocre food. We ordered the lamb shank with lentils and chicken kebabs. There was nothing special about either one of those dishes. The bread was dry & tasteless. It didn't feel like it was freshly made. Also, the prices were a big high for the restaurant. The service was slow and the server was unfriendly. At the start I asked her to explain the different between 2 dishes and she rambled something which we couldn't understand. I decided to go with the eggplant dish which had a picture on yelp. I would not recommend this place for an authentic Persian experience. There are other more friendly and well priced places in the city!
author: Ree M.

description:
Its my first time to this Iranian rest. I got a reservation for 3 .. we had kobideh and joojeh kabab with jewels rice.. its tasted soo good, the meat us tender and tasty as well as the chicken .. rice is just how i love it!the food  tasted like home made ( which is hard to find!) 
My dad tried a pomegranate soup, but wasnt his favorite, probably because it was just a trial for something he never tried before..
The attention and friendly staff are remarkable, the restaurant is very clean with a cosy atmosphere.. i really loved it and would go there every time i visit SF.
author: Rami S.

description: One star is for the service, half the experience in a restaurant is the service. It was terrible, the server YELLED at me for not understanding for asking for another order of food and for tea. She mentioned a "last call" and told me to google it, accused me to of being new to America and not proceeded to yell at me. Food however was great, service AWFUL TERRIBLE. WILL NOT COME BACK AND I ENCOURAGE YOU ALL TO NOT COME HERE. THERE ARE PLENTY OTHER PERSIAN PLACES WITH SOOO MUCH BETTER SERVICE. kindness gets you far in the world. Rudeness gets you no where.
author: Yasmin M.

description: Unique cozy ambiance with art flair and warm costumer service. The Food for most parts were delicious , I suggest Barg or Bakhtiari Kabob ( not a big fan of strong lamb flavor in Koobideh) . Liked the appetizers and Pomegranet Aash was exquisite.  Parking may be an issue but over all it's a great experience! Must go back to try more variety of foods they offer. The pomegranate Icecream was one of a kind and very tasty!
author: C S.

description: Excellent food. I love, love, loved the fesenjan. Had the Persian white wine , it was quite tasty, better than the Persian Shiraz.
author: Heather H.

description:
Wow! A cozy restaurant in SF with no wait for a table, zero hipsters, tasty food, reasonable prices and excellent service.

Came in on a Friday around 7pm. We were seated immediately. We ordered a fantastic glass of Shiraz, the lamb stew, and the boneless chicken kebab. The lamb stew was mouthwatering- the moist pieces of lamb melted in your mouth and were complimented by the eggplant and lentils. The chicken was pretty good too. There was plenty of food and we took home leftovers.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Horrible service! I should have went straight to Maykadeh! Rcvd Barg instead of Soltani, ordered Bakhtiari and the vege plate. I told the person vege with vege. So excited to eat Persian, disappointed that all the 3 dish order came with all salad! Who eats Persian meat with salad?!? I came for PERSIAN FOOD!!!! My First and last time. You won't last long!

I agree with other reviewers, chicken was very dry and the person who takes phone orders does not listen!
author: Luna T.

description: Many Persian restaurants do Kabobs well.  The test of a real authentic Persian restaurant is in their KHORESHES (stews).  Stews are very time-consuming to make, especially GHORMEH SABZI which requires cleaning, finely chopping, and, sautéing a ton of herbs.  The one I had at Anar was the best I've had at a restaurant, and, the closest to my own mother's. The seasoning with the Oman lime was spot on.  The chunks of beef were plenty and cooked perfectly.  Loved it.
author: Azar L.

description:
Simply, the BEST Persian Restaurant in the BAY AREA!!

The food is PHENOMENAL!! Everything, everything is literally perfection! Whether you get kabobs, or more of traditional persian stews (ghormeh sabzi, or ghaymeh). I have never in my life eaten Persian food this tasty. I even ordered soda to go with my food so I could eat more, and I usually never do that (i'm too healthy haha).

In addition to the  great food, the service is excellent. Everyone who works here is so polite, generous, well-mannered and kind (and not to mention, very beautiful) 

This place is perfection, if I ever want Persian food, this is the only place I'll go! I've been to many others, in Walnut Creek, Berkeley, NONE of them come even close. Highly HIGHLY recommend to everyone!
author: Millie P.

description: We got the chicken kabab, veggie kabab, and a lamb dish. The food was really tasty, except that the lamb dish, which was cold. When you order the meal, get half rice and half bread. Those were good quantities. The restaurant was empty when we got them be other people started to stroll in. Getting water is tough because it is given in a jug which fills a table of four glasses just once.
author: Brian G.

description: Decided to get some Persian food while we were in SF and am very glad my gf and I settled on this place. We ordered the chicken kabob and a side of hummus with lavash to share. The chicken was very flavorful and juicy and came with basmati rice, vegetables, and a grilled tomato. The hummus was also great. We later ordered some Baklava with tea and would recommend that as well. Will be coming back here again if we are in SF
author: Alex C.

description: We ordered herbed rice with lam , rice was very good. The lamb lacked flavor . Service was decent . The Soltani kabob was very good but the ground beef kabob tasted of grease . The ice cream and fallodeh were excellent .  Ambience was good . We had to return the doogh (yoghurt drink $5) back since it tasted off . We ordered eggplant dish for appetizer $8, it was very good . Bread and herbs also good . Also ordered a yellow split pea stew that was very good . This dish came with tadiq which is burned rice from the bottom of the pot . It was so hard we could not eat it . Even soaking it with stew did not help to soften it . So left it but the stew was good .  So all in all we will try the place again. Some hits but some small misses that hopefully they can remedy.
author: Star B.

description:
I like the food here and service could be better, however the part that frustrates me is I always call them to order my food for pick-up and they at least 90% of the time don't answer. 

Again, food is great but not happy with the unresponsiveness.
author: Poya O.

description: Good food... good service... friendly and professional staff.... good music.... clean restrooms
author: Neda G.

description:
So far may favorite Iranian restaurant in SF considering both food and pricing.  
Nice staff, cute decor, modern Iranian musicians featured on the playlist. 
Juicy kababs and well sized portions!  Im going back for sure!
author: Leila O.

description:
Spectacular Persian flavors in an upscale setting hidden away in a semi deserted street of San Francisco.

Had lunch with a friend, and didn't want to just go to a hole-in-the-wall place or one of those overpriced SF poser scene eateries. 

This hit the spot!

The Walnut Pomegranate chicken stew was so good: tangy, tart and rich. Kinda la a middle eastern version of a Mexican mole. 

The appetizer with barberries (was like a vegetarian quiche like dish.... so tasty and ethnic. 

And all the kebobs including the vegetable stew that comes with this yummy yogurt. 

It's not cheap, but it's not overly expensive for a city restaurant. 

Really good! I will be bringing my wife here next.
author: Rob G.

description: I brought my parents the first time to this restaurant, and my mom really loved their soup! Now I keep on coming with my husband for delicious kebab and soup, and we enjoy both food and service a lot! I wish they are open after 5 though!
author: Sarah A.

description: Good food but terrible service. We got yelled at by our server for asking for more food! DO NOT GO TO THIS RESTERAUNT!!
author: Mustara M.

description:
#70/100 in 2016

My husband is half Persian so we're always on the lookout for some good Persian eats. This place did not disappoint. We started with the Mirza Ghasemi which was good - very heavy on the garlic. For entrees we shared ghormeh sabzi, one of our favorites - it's a stew with beef and herbs, lamb koobideh - ground lamb kebab that was really juicy, and the joojeh - chicken breast kabob. It's a little pricey, with each entree coming in at about $20, but par for the course in SF. The one appetizer and three entrees were more than enough to feed four people (we left some food behind). We liked our food and would recommend this place to others.

We made a reservation through Yelp for 8:30 and we were the last ones in the restaurant - holding up closing. Dessert wasn't an option because it was so late for the restaurant, so I'd suggest starting your meal by 8 to avoid feeling rushed.
author: Kendra N.

description: Delicious family owned Iranian restaurant. Went there with a few Iranian friends and they even said it was amazing! I got the veggie kabob. It was massive! Definitely enough to share. Also loved all the dips and appetizers. Check this place out!
author: Lindsay L.

description: This is my favorite Persian Cuisine. Not just because of the great quality of food. but, because of the extraordinary staff. they are the nicest people and they make sure you leave with the best experience. its like visiting a friend, who happens to be a great cook and host!
author: Pooya G.

description: Delicious food! Flavors I was not expecting, friendly and patient staff, and excellent quality.
author: Sean L.

description:
I have driven by this place several times but never had the chance to eat their food until now. I cannot believe what I have been missing. I sprung for deliver using Caviar and recommend you either do the same. I'm still so excited of the discovery and already know this place is going to be my new Persian fix. I ordered a wide range of entrees and appetizers and everything was tasty, pretty, and well proportioned. I recommend their appetizer Kashk-e Bademjan. It's surprisingly tricky dish to prepare right and they nailed it. They even made the garnish of mint/yogurt look pretty.

I look forward to bringing family and friends here!
author: Darin E.

description:
This is for delivery.

I ordered two entrees and an appetizer. The food was delicious. However, it was so badly packaged.

By the time it was delivered, half of one of the entrees was spilled in the bag, because the lid wasn't properly closed and the contents were so hot that the plastic containers lost their integrity.

Expected much better.

Also, horrendously expensive. The two entrees and one appetizer cost over $60 not including the delivery charge. I wouldn't have minded if it not for the fact that the portions were tiny and half of one of the entrees was spilled.

Really disappointing.
author: Yan F.

description:
Appetizers were very yummy - eggplant dish and bread.
Pomegranate walnut stew was soooooo sweet, too sweet.
Kebabs were dry, not exciting.
author: Lizzie R.

description: Absolutely scrumptious -- already looking forward to eating here again. Bright, fresh dishes that were so full of flavor. Thank you to our kind waitress and to the kitchen for such a yummy meal. Happy stomach!!
author: Annemarie E.

description: The food at Anar was amazing. My dad and I stopped by for a late lunch while we were in the city, and I'm so glad we did. We had heard so many great things about the food here, and it certainly lived up to our expectations. I had the Fasenjan and my dad had the Joojeh kabob and both were delicious! We both drank Doogh and thought the rose petals were a dreamy touch. Our waitress was also super sweet and attentive. We'll definitely be back with the rest of the family!
author: Adrianna B.

description: We went to this place based on the reviews and it met our expectation. The food is good compared with other Persian restaurant in Bay Area. Chicken was marinated perfectly and cooked just right. The rice was fluffy and tasty. The appetizers were great. I tried their sholeh zard, it was just ok, not great. The staff were friendly and helpful. Overall a great experience. We will come back.
author: Max M.

description: Great, family owned Persian restaurant.  We ordered mirza ghasemi, kashko bademjan, for appetizer and baghali polo with Lamb shank, soltani and barg, all very delicious!  Excellent service, great experience, definitely will be back.
author: Fariba E.

description:
(Review from 1 month ago)

This place is a gem! Who would have known this little place was hiding in SoMa.

First of all, the interior decor is very elegant and cozy at the same time. The employees were very friendly and helpful. We got the fesenjan and the boneless chicken joojeh with a side of rice and salad (and it came with a roasted Roma/plum tomato--couldn't tell which one). The fesenjan was a very interesting dish--it's chicken in a pomegranate sauce. It was a bit tart while also being savory. Definitely want to eat it atop some rice because the flavor is strong and there isn't much texture (in fact, I think having some texture in/on the dish would make it even better). The chicken joojeh--oh, so good! It was strange how grilled marinated chicken could taste so flavorful and buttery, but it was definitely a crowd favorite. And paired with the roasted tomato on the side--Mmm.

I definitely plan to come back in the near future to try something new here! Worth a try if you want to taste something new!
author: Julia N.

description:
Fantastic Persian food with even better service. The atmosphere is very relaxed yet welcoming and the staff (family owned) is lovely. 
Best fesenjoon I have had and the kababs (both chicken and beef) are great as well. 
So happy to have found this place in SOMA!!!
author: Ghazal M.

description:
The ambience is comfortable,  service is good, let's talk about food, food is better then some Iraninan resturants and portions were generous compared to the one in Berkeley. 
They attend to your right away and the place was relatively empty , maybe because we went there after 1.30 pm
We order a kobideeh,  an eggplant dish, and the hardened rice tadeeq not sure if that the correct spelling,  suffice to say, I will visit again to try other dishes they offer. 
 Price wise expect your bill to be around 60++ and we were full when we left the resturant.
author: Liz S.

description: This place is amazing! The food is the best and the service was sweet, courteous and gracious!! And no, I am not hired by the restaurant nor am I a relative of the owners. I am merely a happy customer.
author: Theo B.

description:
Holy smokes! I don't know how to say that in Farsi, but I'm in Sunday's San Francisco Chonicle (http://bit.ly/1pQgJQ8). Based on their suggestion, this is the place where they photographed me for the article because I had a nice dining experience here the week before, and fortunately I was able to get the same high quality of Persian food this time. I first noticed this place when I was taking the MUNI 12-line but really got motivated to try it when a friend of Jamie W.'s and a fellow Yelper, wrote that it was the "BEST Persian food in SF right now" (armand d. - here's his helpful review: http://bit.ly/XvIvuz). That was enough of an endorsement for me, so Jamie and I gave it a go last week.

Well, it's not in a great location unless, I assume, you happen to be coming at... I mean coming to Blow Buddies or the End Up. It's on the speedway block of Harrison between 5th and 6th where all the Bay Bridge traffic pours into the city. Once you enter, it's a modestly decorated place, and you are greeted by one or both of the lovely young women who manage the front of the house. Persian cuisine is not well represented in the city, which is a shame since it has a lot in common with Turkish, Greek and Indian food. Most everything sounded tempting on the menu, so we started with the $7 plate of Dolmeh (Leaf), similar to Greek dolmas in the use of ground beef, rice and grape leaves but different in the use of split peas, herbs and a pomegranate seed garnish (photo: http://bit.ly/1shV47d). Delicious mouthfuls. We then shared two entrees.

The first was the $15 Loobia-Polo, a basmati saffron rice plate with chunks of beef, green beans and all sorts of spices (photo: http://bit.ly/1AMZ2JU). The second was our favorite, the $12 Kabab Koobideh, savory skewers of Persian minced meat kabab made from ground lamb and beef mixed with saffron seasoning, parsley, and chopped onions. It comes with lots of rice which put us on official grain overload (photo: http://bit.ly/1s0ZLB6). The last dish was actually an accident. It was the $12 Dolmeh (Belly Pepper) (photo: http://bit.ly/1pRyLl2) which the server had thought was the other dolmeh dish. When we pointed out that this was the one we wanted, she immediately had the chef make one for us free of charge even though we naively thought the first dolmeh leaves were complimentary. The belly pepper turned out to be a better stuffed vegetable, but by that point, we were completely stuffed.

I was so pleased with the home-style dishes that when the Chronicle asked me to identify a place to be photographed for their story on Yelp Elites, I told them to meet me there the following Wednesday. With my friend Stephanie, we ordered the $6 Naan Panir Sabzi, a cornucopia of pita with fresh scallions, mint and basil leaves and blocks of feta cheese (photo: http://bit.ly/UKxPX6), but the highlight turned out to be the $17 Fesenjan, a chicken stew with ground walnut in a sweet-and-sour pomegranate sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1qT65hV). It was like a Persian version of butter chicken. I even tried a $3 glass of Doogh, a salty yogurt-based drink that I just couldn't warm up to. Service was more variable this time as the restaurant was hopping that night. Hopefully they will find their footing over time.

FOOD - 4 stars...satisfying home-style Persian dishes appear authentic and are quite flavorful
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...comfortable space for groups in a 'hood that's rather challenging
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...attentive service on my first visit...though my second visit saw an increasingly busy operation flail a bit more with long stretches of absence
TOTAL - 4 stars...still a very worthwhile spot to try for authentic Persian food...I think they'll improve their rhythm over time
author: Ed U.

description:
I have been to this place at least twice a month in the past year and would even give it more than 5 stars.The ambiance is super peaceful, cozy and artistically decorated. The food they serve is the authentic Persian food. The appetizers are all very delicious specially the dolmeh is to die for. You should definitely try them. The kebabs are all great. 

If you don't like lamb or even are sensitive to its smell, don't get the koobideh. For me, it tastes tender and great, but a friend didn't like it.

Anar is a family business and the owners are always present, super friendly and accommodating. I love, love Anar
author: Bita G.

description: Be aware! Chicken undercooked -- however server denied and was very rude. You can find much better middle eastern food elsewhere with better quality and much better customer service. I wouldn't try this place if I can do it again and you shouldn't.
author: Rob C.

description:
Super friendly service and very cute restaurant decor. Food portions are also huge so I think it's a pretty good deal for lunch.

That said, I have to go with 3 stars because compared to other Persian restaurants I've been, the food was just okay. I ordered the grilled chicken with salad and rice. Given the other reviews, I was expecting pretty tender meat. Unfortunately I found it to be a bit dry/overcooked. I actually got tired of chewing at some point. 

My bf ordered the grounded lamb meat (koobideh). His lamb was much easier to chew and more tasty. Unfortunately I'm not a fan of lamb meat in general so I couldn't really enjoy it. He seemed to like it a lot though.

It was pretty empty when we came, so it's nice that not much wait is needed.
author: Sophia H.

description: Great portion, descent price, lots of bang for your bucks here in San Fran. Authentic Persian flavor. Can't go wrong with the Baghali polo with the lamb shank. Family owned joint, feels like dining in Tehran. The only imperfection is the location, a little shady. Nothing is perfect, right?!
author: Billy T.

description:
This place is an absolute MUST try. I first had Anar takeout food and was blown away the quality, taste, and value for the food. My Persian friend said it was the best they've had in SF. So I had to try the restaurant and was even more impressed. This is a great spot to go with a small group to catch up (quiet), share different appetizers and dishes, and be treated with great service. My favorite by far was the eggplant dip - the mint on top makes it even better. Then we shared the hummus (so fresh) and veggie kabobs (big portion, great value). We then shared the yogurt/rice pudding dessert - get that! And ask for the hot sauce. Also, try the sumac on your dishes - I am now obsessed with that spice and cook with it often.

I don't know why people have negative reviews about this place.
author: Harmony P.

description: Great food with wonderful and hospitable people! Their dough (yogurt drink), kabob Barg (grilled beef filet) and faloodeh Shirazi are excellent!!
author: Ellee B.

description: I haven't physically been to this restaurant but I have had food to go from this restaurant. I will say that this was my first time ever trying Persian food and was surprised to know how good it is! I had rice (yellow and white) & steak and some kabob (I think it's called). I also had a side of yogurt and shallots (which was bursting with taste) & I had another dish which I forgot the name of it but it was also really good!!!! Everything was bursting with taste and I would definitely come here and try out the food again. For the first time trying this type of food, it was definitely a pleasant experience! So great to know that there is a great Persian restaurant in the city, just wish there was more in the east bay to go to! Come and check this place out!!
author: Anne R.

description:
I remember first coming to this place in the first few months it opened.   It was a bargain and adorable, a mom-and-pop shop whose beautiful daughters worked as waitresses.  As an Iranian vegan, the first question I asked was if they could prepare their stew dishes called "khoreshts" which are the fancy guest-serving ornate Iranian dishes that is served atop rice (in contrast to the "fast food" being the kabobs) without the meat.  They were able to and we were happy, ordering Fesejaan (walnut sauce in a pomegranate syrup stew - a great introductory dish) and Bademjan (Eggplant stew) - both amazing.  Subsequent trips I have tasted their albaloo pollo - sweet cherry rice - along with and Sabzi-Polo (rice with lima beans and dill and other scrumptious spices) and, coming from an Iranian: SOLID.  And then there is the national Iranian dish: Ghormeh Sabzi, a stew mixture of sautéed herbs, consisting mainly of parsley, leeks or onions, coriander, seasoned with the key spice of dried fenugreek leaves - YUM.
The food tasted as good IF NOT BETTER than the other reputable Iranian restaurant in the city:  Maykadeh in North Beach along with the other one Alborz on VanNess.  And like the other restaurants, it was white table cloth and had all the accouterments of being a high brow establishment.  Unfortunately, over time, they raised their prices to the same watermark the other two placed did, taking them out of my "everyday restaurant" category into my "on special occasions" category.  Too bad - I am always hounding for some good Iranian food.
But TWO THUMBS UP to this place.  They are such nice people and they even give a small discount for those who order vegan dishes because of the lack of meat.  I have heard they have good kababs here too.
author: Khash C.

description:
Kinda just strolled in here because it was near my office. Wasn't expecting to be taken on a magic carpet ride..

The Kashk E Bademjan (roasted eggplant dip) was amazing. They serve it with these flatbread pita things which almost look like little magic carpets (throwing in another Aladdin reference..). The dip has the perfect balance of chunkiness, eggplantiness, mint and onion - along with the hint of yogurt.

The Koobideh (lamb kebab) was spiced perfectly. I really love the gamey flavor of lamb and they added just the perfect amount of Persian to the ground lamb. I ended up eating it with the magic carpet pitabread and salad.

Fesenjan - this was definitely the most interesting dish we had. The sauce was full of pomegranate flavor with undertones of walnut. I've never quite had something like that before with chicken and it was pretty eye-opening. Could possibly one of those love it or hate it kind of dishes. I was on the love it side for sure. 

The whole place also had a family-run kind of feel to it - which lent just the right amount of coziness and charm to the restaurant.
author: Henry W.

description:
Amazing food with an even more amazing staff!
I absolutely love it here and it's the perfect place to come with friends or even for a date night
author: Azadeh Z.

description: Their Mirza Ghasemi was amazing. I totally recommend it. The color, taste, and smell was on point. The service was great, too. I would come back for sure.
author: Romina F.

description: Any Persian knows that Tea is an integral part of our culture and dining experience.  What kind of restaurant kicks you out after a meal because they have a hard stop to close at 4?   What happened to service and customer care?   I hope they change their attitude and survive in this business!!!
author: Mariam O.

description: Awesome food, great service, very kind owners. Try the baghali polo with lamb shank, the tahdig appetizer, and the faloode ice cream.
author: Bita H.

description: Beautiful setting, delicious food - there rice is to die for. Love the sour sprinkle they have as condiment really enhances the taste! Ordered the Lamb plate - huge portion so took the other half home for husband to eat. He Loved it too! Very nice friendly service and quick service. Highly recommend!
author: June R.

description: Not sure why there are negative reviews about the service, because every time my family and I have come here everyone is very sweet and accommodating. The pomegranate stew has amazing flavor, though I do think the chicken in it is a bit dry. The koobideh is incredibly flavorful and juicy, one of the best versions I've had. We also had a wonderful eggplant appetizer the last time. I hope this restaurant stays around because it's great!
author: Jen K.

description:
Stopped by for lunch around late afternoon and was greeted by a very pleasant Lady.
We were a party of three and very
hungry.
Ordered Dulmeh and Hummus as 
appetizers which were by far better than any 
I have had in other Persian restaurants . The Dulmeh is absolutely delicious and very original and authentic. It was so good that I ordered some to go as well. Our main dishes were the lamb shank, ghaimeh, koobideh and joojeh kabob and they were all superb and delicious. There is certainly someone in the kitchen with a skilled hand for authentic Persian food. I felt like I was back home in my mothers kitchen. Service was also excellent. Even though I live in the east bay, I won't hesitate to make the trip over the bridge for this food.
author: Majid M.

description:
I wanna say I like this place because honestly the Persian food was very good. We ordered the chicken and lamb rice plates. Honestly both very tasty, came with pita bread, and had perfectly cooked rice.

That being said, the service was absolutely garbage. When we first ordered, we ordered two dishes. The lamb plate and some other thing so my gf and I could share. The waitress said that she wasn't sure if they still had the second thing we ordered and would check for us. Guess what she never came back and we though oh good they have it. 20 minutes later she brings out our lamb dishes and then decides to tell us they're out of the second thing... Now we had to wait another 20 minutes for another dish since the lamb didn't fill neither me nor my gf. On top of that , during our next 20 minute wait for the chicken, the waiter comes up to us and pretty much asks us to leave if we're just gonna sit here and do nothing. Dude didn't realize we were waiting for additional food, saw it coming, and said nvm as he walked away.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Great Iranian food and service.
The food tastes like home made.
One of the good Iranian food spots in the Bay Area.
author: Farid N.

description:
I love the Anar Theme of this restaurant! (Anar=pomegranate). My first time in San Fran, and I came across this after seeing the great reviews. 

I must say my experience was great! The food was really delicious. However, I wasn't a huge fan of the thin bread served with Hummus. Everything else was great! 

Recommend!
author: Tanzina A.

description: This is a family-run restaurant with a personal touch. The portions are HUGE and the food was tasty. The chicken pomegranate stew was very rich and not to my taste. The kebabs were excellent and so was the lamb shank. Be aware that at peak hours, the service can be slow.
author: Zev L.

description:
This place was great. It was our first time having Persian food and it was amazing. Everyone here was fantastic. From lower the window shade to explaining the foods and options to us, we could not have asked for more.

We had home made dolmeh as an appetizer. Delicious. Ordered an extra one. 

Then it was on to some Fesenjan (chicken based stew) and also a lamb kabob as well as a steak kabob. Both were amazing.

It was all delicious. I highly recommend Anar for their delicious food and amazing and friendly staff.
author: Marty M.

description:
Amazing atmosphere, great service and incredible food! Being Persian myself, I felt like I was back home eating my mom's cooking. The attention to detail is perfect here, and it's evident that the food is made with care. 

Being a family owned and operated restaurant, Anar stands out from your everyday commercial Iranian restaurant, and that truly shows in the dishes. They are also very veg-friendly, offering veggie options for many classic dishes that I didn't even know go be made meatless!!

Overall a fantastic experience, I will definitely be back for more.
author: Samaneh Z.

description: Perfect authentic persian food, with pomegranate themed atmosphere and cuisines. Totally recommend this place to first timers and also persian friends.
author: Amir H.

description: Just moved to SF and was on the hunt for a Persian food place so I stumbled upon Anar. Unlike many other Iranian food spots, Anar has a lot more diversity on their menu rather than just kabobs (a lot more home made Iranian dishes) which I really appreciated. Prices were good and the portions were large. Service was great as well. We had the kashk-e-bademjoon to start, and then the koobideh and fesenjan for our entrees. The fesenjan wasn't as sweet as I typically like but still enjoyed it and the other dishes as well. Also their house made dough is great! I will be back to try their other dishes.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Wow. Really? I think this was my first bad eating experience in years.  

There were three of us, coming from David Deida's event in the city, and we were all happy and wanting a unique experiences with Persian food. Doesn't Persian food sound good? We thought so... We were planning to spend probably $90-$100 on dinner. 

The crispy rice appetizer was so hard that all of us thought we were going to break our teeth. I asked to swap it for something else and our waiter was adamant that this was what everybody gets. I tried to reason with her and she would not change her mind. So we paid for the drinks and terrible $8 appetizer and left, and now I get the unique experience of leaving a terrible review. Awwwesome.
author: Rob P.

description:
The fesenjan here was so legit.  If you haven't tried it, you're in for a treat.  The crushed up walnuts and pomegranate molasses was spectacular, and the rice alongside was perfectly cooked.  I couldn't finish it, and I with I was fatter so I could have shoved more in my mouth.

Come check it out!
author: Drew M.

description: I love Persian food because I'm Persian . I ordered kabab kobideh ,and tadig + khoroshteh geyme & gorme sabzi . Like the service very much ,and everything was awesome . The only problem that I can talk about the quality of kabab kobideh wasn't 5 star . I went there once ,and I hope next time I'm going for 5star ...
author: Amir H A.

description:
I'm not Persian but my boyfriend is and this was his first Persian New Year away from his family. We definitely wanted to get some authentic Persian food to celebrate on our own. We chose Anar because it was super close to our apartment. 

It's family owned and really cute. The food was good and they even had a table setup with traditional Persian New Year items. The restaurant interior is a little outdated, the springs in my chair were broken and kept squeaking but that didn't hinder from the experience that much. 

However, the bummer came when they ran out of Tahdig Crispy rice. (My favorite dish that my boyfriend's mother makes and also the main reason I wanted to go)  Running out of one of the most popular dishes at 6PM on Persian New Year seemed really messed up to me. We even asked/begged if they could make more for us as we had our heart set on it and they declined. You would think with 3 hours before closing they would just make some more for us. I was really turned off by that considering it was a special occasion and not just a random dinner.

All in all though, it was enjoyable. I'm sure we will return based on the location being so close to us, but hopefully I get to try the Tahdig next time!
author: Paisley P.

description: Very grumpy girls who have zero skills of hospitality. They kept asking if we were done. We reserved the table ahead using Yelp. The food was very mediocre and I'm surprised to see other 5 star reviews. Persian food is supposed to be very flavorful but the lamb shank was very mild and tasteless. The dill rice seems to be very sub par and I definitely didn't like their selection of appetizers. The chai, is just plain black tea and make sure you are aware of that. What else ? I wouldn't go there the second time.
author: Deepthi M.

description:
While the area surrounding anar might take you aback, this place is definitely the adventurous treat. 

Service was impeccable and the kebab Koobideh was amazing. The meat had the perfect balance between beef and lamb. I'd suggest a mixture of half salad and half rice.

Service was also very friendly. Each of the four servers checked in on our table to make sure everything was great.

Happy foodie adventure!

Tip: order the uber while you're inside the restaurant.
author: Jonathan T.

description: If want a great Persian restaurant, try Anar. Family-owned and family-run with mom also cooking the food. No wonder it tastes like it is home-cooked. Delicious kabobs.
author: Alidad V.

description:
Polite staff
Yummiest, or one of the yummiest Persian food in SF. 
This is my second time here and it has been nothing but pleasant.
This is family business and they are really sweet and really fast with orders. 
Try FESENJOON! Or Soltani. The BEST!!
author: Sahar G.

description: Excellent food and service. We felt welcome. Everyone was friendly and hospitable. The food is delicious.  I would say this place is top 3 Persian food in Bay Area.   Will definitely come back. I had the combo of beef and chicken.  The restaurant is clean, simple and warm.
author: Joe M.

description:
We were in the area, when visiting San Francisco for father's birthday, decided on middle eastern for dinner and this place popped up on yelp! What an awesome choice!

Was warmly greeted by the host! The atmosphere is cozy and quite but small. 

My father decided to order the Cornish hen, but we're told they no longer served that, because the cook time is long, that was disappointing.

Ordered a few of the sak ad Shirazi, they were good but expensive for a small bowl.

I ordered the the soltani, the luleh tasted kinda weird,  but the joojeh was bomb! The rice was a good portion.

For dessert ordered the faloodeh!  Let me just tell ya it was amazing! It came with fresh pomogranted and juice with a side of lime, defenilty worth the price. Can't wait to back for more!
author: Bernadette E.

description:
Super bad service! Never book a table. Doesn't worth it!

Here is what has happened. Called them at 5:45 for table at 6pm. They confirmed the reservation. I show up on time and then they say it will take 20 min or so. The restaurant was almost quarter full. I don't see why they couldn't accommodate. What pissed me off was the lack in professionalism in they way they dealt with the situation. The She was angry and asking me to hush, which was super rude!
author: Mahmoud A.

description:
The food here is good. We ordered the koobideh with joojeh kabob, hummus, and soltani.  The koobideh was juicy and the hummus was awesome.  In general, the texture was perfect.  The service here was attentive and friendly.  The ladies who took care of our order were great.

The location of this restaurant seems to be in a shady part of town. As we turned the corner, I felt a little uncomfortable.  The outside area is a contrast to the interior of the restaurant. The inside of the restaurant is chic and clean.
author: JD W.

description:
Writing a bad review for this makes me really sad since the food was amazing. I came with a friend and we had the chicken and lamb rice plates. They both came with pita bread and perfectly made rice. It was honestly some of the best Persian foods I've ever had. 

HOWEVER, if you include the service, this place barely even deserves a star. When we first ordered, we ordered two dishes--a lamb plate and this other soupy dish that I wanted to try. The waitress told me that she wasn't sure if it was still available but would go back and check to make sure they have it before she placed the order. 20-30 minutes later, she comes out with the lamb dish and only then tells us that they don't have the second dish. So now we're two people sharing one dish and lack another one. They ask us if we want another dish. Since the food was good, we decided to place another order (but it took another 20 minutes or so). We finished the first dish relatively quickly since we were hungry and were waiting for the second plate to come out. A waiter comes up to us and says that if we weren't eating then we should leave. We had to tell him that we were waiting for our other dish to come--keep in mind, this wasn't even a busy hour. There was literally one other couple at this place when we went. 

If it wasn't for the service, I'd probably give this place 5 stars. (Come for the food and not for the service)
author: Victoria C.

description: This is hands down some of the best Persian food I've ever had. The koobideh and barg kebabs were excellent. Gheimeh bademjan was my favorite. Definitely go for the desert. Service was excellent. Authentic atmosphere and music.
author: Hel D.

description:
Chai tea, roasted eggplant, lamb chop, chicken breast, ice cream and rice noodle

The food---The lamb chop is the best I have tried, roasted eggplant is yummy, the rice noodle desert is delicious with interesting texture.  Chicken breast is moist. 
 The food portion is much bigger than Salazar.  

The service-- our waitress was very attentive-- she made sure my tea got refilled.
