Will come back for sure
author: Sf A.

description:
Loved their Ash E Anar (Vegetarian Pomegranate Soup) which was made of Rice, lentil, garbanzo, sauteed onion, Persian herbs, and pomegranate paste.

Shole-Zard was too sweet.
author: Priyanka L.

description: Delicious food and very friendly service. I've been here about 5 times and its always excellent. My favorite dish is the Fesenjan - chicken with pomegranates.
author: Eli W.

description: Do yourself a favor and give this place a try. Location is a bit out of the way, but you will not be disappointed. I have ordered delivery on several occasions and food is always fresh, flavorful and perfectly prepared. Favorites are the roasted eggplant dip, dolmas ( I mean seriously I could eat these for breakfast, lunch and dinner... one bite and I wanted to give the chef a hug), gheymeh bademjan, and fesenjan. So yum. Just go. Now.
author: Katie M.

description:
The very first time when my husband and I came to Anar was 3 weeks after they opened this place!!
It tasted good and totally felt homemade, not oily or anything but textured needed to be adjusted a bit ( more spice)....
We kept coming no matter what because they were super nice all the time.
Yesterday when I brought my family here after a long time, everything was spot on... It tasted amazing and texture was PERFECT!! All employees are super nice and it's the best Iranian restaurant in SF in my opinion.
Definitely keep coming back
author: Faranak R.

description: There are very few options in this area and I'm glad we found this place! We got seated right away when we walked in for dinner on Wednesday evening around 8. The service was great with our server providing good recommendations and checking in on us throughout the meal. I really enjoyed the Gheymeh Bademjan, it was a hearty stew with lamb and eggplant in a tomato sauce that came with a giant serving of rice. My friend had the Joojeh kebab which came with a combination of rice and salad - I found the chicken to be a little dry. I thought the prices were a bit steep with my stew being $20 and the kebabs being $16 but the portions here were very generous and can easily be enough for lunch the next day! If I find myself in this area again, I'd definitely eat at Anar again.
author: Gloria N.

description:
I have been to this restaurant several times. The food is decent though a bit pricy. The yogurt soda in particular is way overpriced, $4????  C'mn......
The staff was very courteous and service was prompt.  One thing that I couldn't understand was that they won't even provide the basic bread and butter that all Persian restaurants provide, and the only one time that they did,  the bread was cold and just out of the plastic.  Some Persian restaurants even offer herbs and feta cheese for free.  All in all,  I had a good experience,  but I  hope the owners take these very basic issues seriously and address them.
author: Reza B.

description:
Amazing!!! Some of the best tasting food I have ever had. The chicken and vegetables are cooked to perfection and steaming with vibrant, crisp flavor. The sauces are out of this world with a seemingly impossible fusion between fruity sweetness and savory delight. The desert was original and refreshing.

If you're looking for a unique and authentic experience then come here. You won't regret it.
author: Sean M.

description:
Lovely Iranian restaurant tucked away. We almost missed it walking past.

Saturday evening, we arrived as a table of four, but we hardly needed a reservation. Plenty of empty tables around (for now!). Great combination of vegetarian and non-vegetarian options. I ordered the Joojeh (chicken breast) with bread. Very generous portions including much more rice than I could eat.

My dining companions ordered a mix of vegetarian and meat dishes, mains and soups. Everyone was quite pleased with the feast before us. The staff was also courteous, prompt, and competent.
author: Irene C.

description: Great place to have a quiet lunch. The food was great and the service was wonderful. It seems like a family ran restaurant. I had a great time.
author: David M.

description: I'm from Saudi Arabia and for me this is the best Middle Eastern restaurant in SF. The food and the spices are he best even compared to the food we have back home. The Kobedeh is my favorite but honestly all the dishes are really good. Everyone I've ever taken to this restaurant loves it. The staff is very friendly and welcoming, and the whole place has a family vibe to it. I've been coming to this place for two years and the quality has always been top-notch.
author: Mohammad A.

description: This was the first time I had Persian food and I was impressed. The lamb was so good. The portion is large and the restaurant is pretty clean. The chicken wasn't that great though. It was rough and compared to the lamb it was kind of mild. So order the lamb!
author: Alicia J.

description:
I don't like "smoked" food, and I don't like eggplant, but the smoked eggplant dish (Mirza Ghassemi) might be the most delicious appetizer I've had in all of san francisco. All I wanted after we finished it was another order of the same.

Don't even get me started on the staff. Welcoming, helpful, and patient. This place is really, really, really great.
author: Arrel G.

description: ATTITUDE!  Service is horrendous!  Never been to any restaurant where you are not able to order dessert or coffee/tea after your meal.  Kitchen in this place closes between 4-5 afternoon as they seem to have a hard time boiling water for tea or plating a pre made dessert.  Food is good.  Well prepared and flavorful.  Back of the house seems to run much better than front of the house.  Recommendation to Anar....get new servers, drop the attitude and keep the cook.
author: Ramin K.

description:
I've been a huge fan of Persian food ever since I first had it in college, so I thought I'd give the new kid on the block a shot. Meeting up with a friend I haven't seen for a while, we ordered their:

* Kashk-E Bademjan - A pureed (or puree-like) eggplant and yogurt appetizer, similar to the texture of hummus, meant to be eaten with pita bread. Good flavor, and overall, pretty enjoyable.

* Kaba Koobideh - Also fairly tasty, and, while we were both experienced a little sticker shock at first, looking at the menu, we realized that their serving sizes were huge. So, yes, while one of these dishes is around the $20 mark, unless you eat a LOT, one dish should be enough to share. I also understand why someone else said Anar served a slightly healthier version of Persian food: their stuff is not as oily/buttered/salted as the stuff I'm used to, for better or worse.

So, while everything was pretty solid, I wasn't so wowed that I'd give them a four. A solid 3.5 though. My only real complaint was the same as the previous Persian place I went to: I'm still used to yogurt being served as part of the meal, not a separate side that you have to order, so that still irks me.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A fairly large venue with plenty of accessibility. It doesn't seem to get too crowded around dinner time, and even if they do, maneuvering around shouldn't be too difficult.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description: I like their food. A cozy restaurant with great dolmeh. I like it that they brought us robe annar (pomegranate extract).
author: Nasim S.

description:
Absolutely DELICIOUS! I'm Iranian and understand the difference between Mediterranean food & Iranian cuisine. Anar reminds me of home, my mother and grandmothers unforgettable dishes, and honestly it's like eating in Iran. San Francisco is very limited for Iranian food, but Anar is perfect for lunch or dinner and the price is lower than the rest. For lunch I had Gheymeh Bademhan, a tasty tomato stew with roasted eggplant, yellow split peas and juicy lean beef. But you can't just have one dish, so traditionally I accompanied my meal with salad Shirazi, Tadik (crispy rice!) and a fresh acidic yogurt drink called Doogh. So delicious...the restaurant is family operated employing two lovely ladies from Iran! 

Trust me, you gotta eat here. I'll be returning again and again, again, again, again, again...
author: TVAT T.

description:
We came here for take out. Got the Jojeh Kabob and the Koubideh Kababo. Both were solid! The Jojeh was very tender and juicy. 

We also got some steamed veggies which we didn't care for...but will try some other dishes next time!
author: Mimi T.

description: Enjoyed a Sunday lunch at this lovely restaurant. The two ladies working there were very kind and helpful. Had the Ash-E-Anar soup. It was delicious.
author: Rita L.

description: I think Anar is authentic and fresh Persian food. They have courteous and attentive service. Their food is just about as good as it gets. My part had the yogurt and cucumbers, the eggplant with yogurt sauce which was almost like my mom makes it. Their kabob was seasoned just right and cooked well. I will state my mother got the Cornish hen kabob. It was the best dish. The chicken is marinated with olive oil, lemon, saffron and lightly seasoned. It was deliciously juicy. I have no complaints. The family who runs this restaurant is doing a great job and I wish them nothing but success. I will go again and bring friends and family.
author: Kambiz K.

description: Food is amazing and convenient location. I wish they delivered! My favorite items are the crunchy rice (tadeeg), chicken kabob, and the dessert (falludeh).
author: Michelle M.

description:
I had heard this place was good, but it exceeded my expectations.

PROS
- The food was delicious, and portions were not as small as you might expect.
- I expected the steak to be tough, but it was so tender I could cut it with my fork.

CONS
- The hummus was meh.

TIPS
- The lamb might be the best I've ever had.
author: Drew P.

description: This place was a surprise win.  I more or less randomly picked it out for a dinner with some friends, and came out 100% satisfied.  The neighborhood is "in transition" so you may think you're walking in the wrong direction, but persist.  I had the fesenjen, which was amazing, and my friends had the barg and koobideh, and they were also entirely pleased with their meals. The hummus was also quite good.  This will be a place to which I return!
author: John T.

description:
I really wanted to like this place...since there are so few good Persian restaurants here, and it is walking distance from my place.
Pro: roasted eggplant appetizer was delicious; well seasoned and smooth. 
Cons: I was not a fan of their bread...it was cold and unappetizing. They only had one vegetarian entree...it was decent, but the vegetable portion was small. The plate was mostly rice. For the price, I was not impressed.
My bf had their kebob koobideh, which he was was pretty good but nothing amazing.
Maybe their other dishes are better?
author: Nancy Z.

description:
We've been craving Persian food and Yelp led us here. Traffic can be a bitch, since it's close to the freeway on ramp. It's a gorgeous space inside...definitely a feminine influence.
We started off with some drinks - a pomegranate juice that looked house-made and "doogh", the yogurt and mint drink. Both drinks were good. The yogurt drink was thick, slightly tangy, and the amount they give you is a lot. It isn't salty. I couldn't finish my glass! Our shared appetizer was the Kashk e Bademjan, a delicious roasted eggplant meant to be eaten with thin lavash bread. Definitely would order this again. The bread was fresh and they were generous with the amount. We had a ton to take home.
It took a while for the food to come out. Good thing we weren't too hungry. DH ordered the Shishlik which is a lamb chop dish served with basmati (?) rice and a grilled tomato. He liked the flavor, but I thought it was too gamey. His quote: "Lamb that actually tastes like lamb." LOL! Also, each chop was really tiny. He felt is wasn't a good value at $26...it was one of the most expensive things on the menu.
My dish was the classic lamb/beef Koobideh ground meat kabobs. At $14, this was a better deal. It came with the same rice, a pat of butter, roasted tomato, and raw, sliced onions. Flavor was fine, but I wished the meat was slightly more charred. However, the tomato was a bit too charred.
The rice is kind of odd. It's a long-grained variety, but seemed too soggy. Perhaps whomever cooked it used too much water.
I almost forgot to mention the dessert: saffron ice cream with pistachios. Flavor was awesome, texture was not. However, soggy pistachios and some iciness seems in line with other Persian ice creams I've had. Portion size was generous...I can still recommend it at $6.
Overall experience was good. Seemed quite authentic and not "Americanized". There were real Persians eating here, not just hipsters. :) Really liked the atmosphere. Wait staff was super friendly and helpful. We got all of our utensils and a small container of water. It is a slow dinner and kind of pricey (about $75 total with tax and tip), so we're probably not going to be back real soon.
author: Kari C.

description: Someone needs to tell the young ladies that work there to learn some mannerism and customer service. While I completely understand that you need a reservation, especially on Fridays and weekends, I just don't need the sass and sarcasm that came along with their explanation. We were super polite and patient enough with the staff to see what they could do and they were still rude and condescending. My family and I have already decided that we won't be back. There are PLENTY of other Persian restaurants like Maykadeh, and especially Shalizar that I can go to that will provide excellent service and great food.
author: Tata R.

description: Really good food, friendly service....i came here with my friend and tried fish curry and bolani it was really good...
author: Muhammad S.

description:
This is my kind of place - the owners are on-site and they care about your experience. The food is good, the wine is acceptable. My friends won't always go out to eat with me because they consider me too adventurous for their taste. But I just think I like new and interesting stuff. So this place is Persian (you can call it Iranian, but Persian is a lot more romantic) and the dishes are traditional Persian fare. Everything I tried was good.

I take a passing interest in restaurant design and I'm always impressed when someone can make a shoebox look good. The owners did their own interior design here, with the sister doing the artwork, and it came out with a very nice feel. Friendly & attentive service.
author: nemo t.

description: So good! Solo on biz trip and decided to try something new. Did not disappoint. Got the eggplant and dolmeh to start. Both amazing! Chicken kabab for main bone in. Don't recommend with bone- but  otherwise good. Great for something unique. Seems super authentic too based on everyone here :)
author: Jon T.

description: I loved the decoration and nice environment . The food was good too. We had baghali polo and bakhtiiari both were delcious try it !
author: Mary M.

description:
The atmosphere, pleasant artsy. food very authentic , service very good.
Would go back with more of friends and families for sure. 
We had bagali polo and jojeh kabab both were yummy 
Oh ya don't forget maste-moser and doogh
author: Mike B.

description: Owners of this place have NO idea what Customer Service means.. Waitresses are moody and extremely unprofessional. I would assume they are part of the family who runs the restaurant, otherwise they should be fired on the spot. I would never come again....
author: Boris G.

description: Great little neighborhood Persian restaurant. Food is really exceptional and the staff very welcoming.
author: Butterfly S.

description: Terrible customer service! They had us ask for water, bread, salt, etc! One lunch took us 2 hours! No itemized receipt!
author: Mojtaba S.

description: Waitress was really friendly, especially to our 2,5 year old Son. Delicious food! Plates were bigggg!! Nice Place, good atmosphere and childfriendly.
author: Mark J.

description: Fantastic food and amazing service. Would highly recommend this place for anyone who wants some authentic Persian fare at a very reasonable price. The wine selection is also great. They stayed open about 20 minutes over because we came a little on the later side but never rushed us once. Overall, a gem in San Francisco.
author: Vihan S.

description:
This was my second time at this restaurant. First time was for dinner which was okay. And this time for lunch with my husband. We were extremely disappointed. Very rude service. First the waitress got mad because we wanted somewhere away from the front door. It was cold and the restaurant was empty. The waitress gave was an attitude and mentioned we are taking a table for 4. My husband said if 4 people come in we'll gladly give up our seats. We ordered Taj dig with ghormeh sabzi. Tahdig was microwaved and chewy. Ghormeh sabsi had no meat in it. Eggplant with lamb shank had a small piece of lamb. When I mentioned it the waitress insisted there were plenty of lamb in there. Typically at a Persian restaurant you are served with bread butter herbs and onions. This was not the case. In fact we had to ask for onions to eat with our kabob. Not even once the waitress came to check if we needed anything. If I'm paying over $20 per dish for lunch I would expect a little more hospitality and care. I left no tip and wrote on the bill. "Learn some hospitality". I was very offended the entire time at the restaurant. Upon leaving the waitress shouted. Don't ever come back. Very classy. Instead of trying to find out why and perhaps correct the manner. We were yelled at. 
I work at a company that provides catered lunches. I have been Wanting to add this restaurant to the list of the caterers. Today's lack of care, quality and rudeness of the service changed my mind. And you can bet I will never be back.
author: Henrick V.

description: Zero customer service , food is okay . Two girls who work there act like you owe them something . Do not recommend it . That was last time for me
author: Mehrdad A.

description:
My friend and I strolled by this place for lunch.
I ordered the beef kebab and it was phenomenal.
No waiting and hardly anyone was there when we showed up on a saturday.
Staff was friendly and courteous.
author: Michael C.

description: We had kuku sabzi (herb frittata with barberries), barberry rice with salmon, and ash-e-anar, a lentil & chickpea soup with pomegranate & herbs. Oh, and pomegranate iced tea. Everything was wonderful. The salmon was perfectly cooked with a crispy crust; the soup was just incredibly good - tangy and rich - a perfect light lunch by itself. I'd go back just to grab another pomegranate iced tea - sweet, sour, and perfectly astringent to balance. I don't know a lot about Persian food, but I like all the flavors (dill, barberries, pomegranate, saffron, pistachios, eggplant etc) and can't wait to explore more of the menu.
author: Lulu L.

description:
Really good Kebabs  (was more like skinny yummy plank thin pieces of steak ) I had the steak kebab with rice n ordered med Rare n that came out the way I wanted it. My friend had the lamb n beef n he loved it. Decent sized portions.  
The apps were yummy too, n try their dip with greens in it... was super good. Hummus was the only one I thought was ok. :)
author: ThuZ W.

description:
Worst service ever! I would give zero stars if I could. The soltani came and the taste was horrible like it was old. I asked to send it back and get the chicken breast instead. They charged us for two meals. When we asked why, they said because we ate half of the beef. I was scared to swallow the first piece of beef let alone half of the order. I really didn't want food poisoning. This is just one of the awful moments we had here. Our waitress kept rolling her eyes anytime we asked for something. Very rude. I'm Armenian and I'm very aware of the persian culture as my bff is also persian. I would not recommend this place to you if you'd like to enjoy your meal. I could go on but I'll spare you boring details. Save your time and money, it's not even worth it.

Oh, and you spell wine with an E. Get it straight!
author: Nicole R.

description: Great place to get takeout.  Their koobideh (ground lamb kabob) is really really good.   Nice flavors combined with very finely ground texture - probably the best koobideh I've had.  It comes with a ton of buttery rice for an extremely filling meal.  The chicken kabobs are decent but not in the same league as the koobideh.
author: Simon L.

description: Review is for costumer service as we never tried the food and had to cancel our plan of a BD party the night of. If you are a group, don't even bother attempting to go there as they are not accommodating and set up strange rules last minute like limit of items ordered, number of credit cards, etc. competitor Persian restaurants in the area do a much better job with their costumers and should be tried instead!
author: Me M.

description: Wow, must visit! Will not be disappointed! I got the tea and koobideh with the salad mixed with rice. It was soo good! If there was a special event, I would love to bring all my guest to this place!
author: Miguel B.

description:
Experience was terrible. Went for a family dinner early Sunday evening and my sister had a bad piece of meat with her entree. She asked for chicken instead and they still charged us for the first entree as well as an extra skewer of chicken. My husband only ordered grilled vegetables and they charged us $19 for one skewer- that is more than an entire dinner on their menu and didn't even come with rice or salad. 

Don't get me started on the fact that they charge you for bread! No Persian restaurant EVER charges for bread especially when we got a side of yogurt and cucumber as an appetizer. When we asked them about the bill, the owner and the entire family came out of the restaurant, the waitress yelled at us in front of all the other diners, and someone from the family followed us outside and further harassed us as we left. Never going back. 

Don't waste your time, there are so many great restaurants in SF to waste an evening in this shady part of SoMa.
author: Jennifer R.

description: This is one of my favourite finds. The service is great, the food is fantastic and the venue very warm and welcoming. On this night we had the eggplant starter, joojeh and koobideh plates. I'm certainly no expert in Persian cuisine and only have Lavash in the Inner Sunset to compare to (which also has a very special place in my heart), but I'm very happy with the food here. Ill be back again and again.
author: Kiki Y.

description:
I don't give many five star reviews, but I feel this place deserves it.

My bf and I took lunch together and decided to try out Anar.  He ordered the Kabob Koobideh, and I ordered the Fesenjan.  They were both mouth watering good.  I'm picky with rice, but the rice that accompanied the dishes were cooked to perfection - not too dry, not too moist.  The Koobideh, though not healthy, had a very great flavor -- not that severely game-y flavor that meat (especially lamb) has if not cooked the right amount.  As a recent fan of Fesenjan, I've been ordering it at any Persian place I go, and the version here is on par with the version at Lavash.  A true stew...not too watery as some places make it. 

I thought the service was wonderful, and anyone who complains about it, clearly has a severe defect in their social skills. 

The place is small, and I can see that it would be challenging to get a table during peak hours, but either make a reservation in advance, or go during off peak hours.  This isn't something that should be complained about :).  

Overall, I do plan on coming here again.  The area's fine, the decor is beautiful (loved the artwork), and the food was delicious.
author: Ghizal A.

description: Anar is an excellent restaurant serving Persian food. It is a family-run restaurant with reasonable prices for quality food, art on display and great service. I can't wait to go back!
author: Hamid M.

description:
I went there with a couple of friends hoping to have a good experience with Persian food.  The amount of food, price, and service did not meet the Persian standards at all.  I have been to many Persian restaurants in Bay Area, this one does not even deserve a single star, but I had no choice to give zero star. Here are some facts:

Service:  we had to wait at least 20 minutes to get our $7 sabzi which was three small microwaved pieces of flat bread with extremely wet green vegetables and radish. There was a piece of feta cheese hidden under the wet stuff. 
 
Foood: food was not bad but the portions were kids size .
We only had one Bodemjon ( egg plant) for $18 dollars. Anyhow, i really love persian food but this place is not my cup tea.
We left the place without getting any dessert. By the way, the pictures on Yelp is not what you get at the restaurant.
Overll, the place is pricey, and food is not that great. I really like the  An bokherian  to sincerely( your food lover) .
My friend told me that their speciality is , persian An with An pollo with little bit of Estefragh that is similar to Babaghanoush .
author: Josh S.

description: Excellent food and very nice environment. The restaurant staff give you a very warm and welcoming feeling. Food is fantastic, homemade style, tasty and fresh. One of the best persian foods in the bay area. Totally recommend it. Try Chicken Kabob (Jujeh) with bone, so good!
author: Hamid H.

description:
A Hidden Gem in SF.
Great food, great service, great everything. 
The taste of their hospitality is as good as the food.
Look forward to coming back here from San Diego.
author: f s.

description: A little gem in Soma with fantastic authentic food.  It's refreshing to find a relaxed spot to enjoy Persian food as opposed to other options within the city.  I ordered the baghali polo with the filet mignon (Barg) and it was phenomenal.  The staff is very friendly and they suggest other side options in case you're not familiar with the food; very helpful for non-Persians.  The prices are fair especially to other restaurants in SF.  The ambiance is cozy and has a home-like feel to it, so it's perfect to enjoy hearty food.  I highly recommend this spot!!!
author: Parinaz A.

description:
Anar is one of the hidden gems of San Francisco. I'm a transplant from LA and I'm aware of what good Iranian/Persian tastes like, having lived in Westwood and Brentwood. Simply put, Anar can stand up to the best that Los Angeles has to offer. 

The kabobs on the menu are all very good and excellent but the hidden gem in the menu is the Zaershk Polo which is a chicken and rice disk served with a special tomato sauce. The meat simply falls off the bone and the rice with dry fruits mixed in it is simply outstanding. This is by far the best combination of chicken and rice I've had. That's huge because being Indian and having been raised in the Middle East, I've had every possible combination of rice and chicken. 

The appetizers are pretty standard and you can't really go wrong with any of them (yes, I have tried them all). If I was to choose one I'm go with the Badamjaan( eggplant purée). As mentioned earlier the kabobs are excellent, juicy succulent and tender meat. 

The place is run by a Persian family with the mom and dad cooking food back in the kitchen and the daughters running the show. The hospitality, service and response is great and it feels like you are eating at someone's house and not at a fancy restaurant though the ambience is pretty fancy. 

Insider tip: Skip the desserts and order the special Persian tea. Great and light way to end a fantastic meal.
author: Toufeeq H.

description:
Excellent and authentic Persian food.  Been a few times and at least 20%-40% of patrons are Persians which is important!

Rice was perfect.  Hot, steamy and just the rice texture.
author: J H.

description:
i am Persian , and that's not Persian food taste at all.  me and my wife  had dinner  there we found the place on yelp and  had easy parking. 
we ordered kabab kobidah and kabab barg . the service was not bad . food was horrible.
i don't recommend it @ all the food that they bring for the pricing that they charge it is not worth it.
author: Navid Y.

description: Amazing food, excellent vegetarian options too and the service was awesome. The barg and tadig are delicious. The ladies that worked there were so nice to our 2.5 year old and we really enjoyed our evening out.
author: Maryam P.

description: I was really excited about a persian restaurant in SOMA, but unfortunately they don't make their food with quality ingredients, I would not recommend this place, if you have some time please get an uber to Lavash restaurant
author: P E.

description: Lol i think i saw "Tannaz R" at Anar on friday with balloons n stuff, I was eating while you came in and saw the young lady came to welcome you and you didn't even let her talk and basically attacked her and then asking for the owner because they didn't have tables available! The ladies are always really nice to everyone because of course they want business as i know its their own restaurant! I think they were polite trying to find a table for you and you were the rude one lol i think your review is funny. Why gotta be rude for a simple table and then call them rude? By looking at your yelp reviews i can tell you really are pissed at everyone accusing them of being rude with no manners haha, maybe you should calm down a little and not think everyone hates you.
author: Roxane O.

description:
I've been here a few times now and am ready to review it. This is my favorite Iranian restaurant in the Bay Area, and I've been to Shalizaar, Alborz, Lavash, and Maykadeh. The food is as good if not better than any of the others, and it is the most reasonably-priced. The wait staff are also very nice and helpful if you have questions. I think this is a family-run place and it definitely has that feel. Also, the portions are very large. 

The dishes I've had have all been great. They are:

(1) Kabob Soltani. This is one skewer of marinated steak (barg), one skewer of ground beef and lamb (koobideh), and rice. All three were fantastic. I'm typically not a huge fan of koobideh, but they have spiced theirs perfectly. 

(2) Joojeh Kabob. This is one skewer of grilled chicken with rice. Again, excellent flavor and texture.

(3) Fesenjan. This is a great dish that many non-Iranians probably don't know about. It is chicken and rice with a sauce made from crushed walnuts and pomegranate syrup. It is a sweeter-tasting dish, and I highly recommend this to people who haven't had it before. 

My only suggestions on improvements would be:

(1) Maybe keep the water bottles in the refrigerator. My table went through two bottles of water and both were room temperature. Or I could've just asked for ice...

(2) Our entrees came out just a few minutes after the appetizer was brought out. I know it's probably difficult to time this properly, but I think there should be a longer gap between appetizer and entree so that the customer doesn't have to choose between finishing the appetizer (and letting the entree get cold) or switching over to the entree (and letting the appetizer get cold). 

(3) No complimentary bread. Of course the entree portions are large enough that you will not leave here hungry. But for whatever reason it just seems like if an Iranian restaurant doesn't bring out bread and greens/cheese, something is missing. 

But regardless of these three critiques, this is by far my favorite Iranian place and I will continue to visit and recommend it to my friends.
author: John S.

description: Cute restaurant, not in the best neighborhood. No parking then again it goes for most of the restaurants in San Francisco, good customer service, Kabobs are below average, the koobodeh kabob has lamb in it, the chicken is dry & hard because they use breast meat, the barg was semi ok but the one we got was old & had an after taste & was burned. Rice portions are very little. Persians eat a lot of rice. At least bring more rice for Persians. The soup & the stews are very good.
author: Fred F.

description:
OMG I am so glad that I found a Persian food place in the city that is both reasonably priced and close to home. I use to go to a Persian restaurant in North Beach and another in Downtown Berkeley. The former was clearly over priced and the later was just too far. I stumbled upon this jem while I was walking in the neighborhood looking for the Bed & Bath. 

The people who worked here are super nice. The service were adorable. I ordered a Kashke Bademjan (eggplant dish) and a Kabob Kobideh. I want to start by saying the Kashke Bademjan was the best I have had. Perfect mix of olive oil and consistency with the egglplant. Unbelievable. The Kobdideh was very high quality too. "Fake" Persian Restaurants will add too much fat to their Kobideh to save meat, causing the final product to be soggy OR not put enough much fat to their Kobideh, causing it to come out very dry. The Kobideh here was a perfect mix. 

I will definitely bring my Persian friends here and be proud to show them what an Asian found!! :)
author: Guang H.

description: Well-done food, friendly service, and a warm and cozy atmosphere. Great local place. Love the yogurt drink, dish of juicy vegetables, and chicken stew with tangy pomegranate sauce.
author: Katie B.

description:
I was recommended this place by my friend and was initially very happy with it. This place has every quality you want to see in a great restaurant. 
The owners are friendly and engaging. 
Anar is amazing from every point of view. I am totally impressed by their services!!! 
The staff is super friendly and the food is amazing. I love this place.
author: Sahar J.

description: Arrived at 11:40 for lunch. Don't open till 12. Restaurant totally empty. Wouldn't let me wait inside. Hate being treated like garbage.
author: Eater S.

description:
Don't let the name fool you, I do know my Persian food.

I've lamented the lack of good Persian food north of San Jose and I'm really happy to this place opened up in San Francisco. This probably surprises people, but SF is severely lacking in it's Persian food options, with very few options to be had. Maykadeh in North Beach is still a reliable choice but this place is much more accessible and has a cozier, family feel to it. 

The food was great. Within our group of four, we ordered the Joojeh (chicken), Koobideh (ground beef/lamb), Shishlik (lamb chops) and Soltani (a combination of Koobideh and Barg, which is like the Iranian version of filet mignon). We didn't try any of the stews (we usually reserve that for home cooking) but everything we ate was excellent. We ordered the yogurt and eggplant appetizer, which were solid as well. If you are given the choice between rice and bread, pick the rice, as the bread is your standard lavash.

The focus is on the food, which is good, so don't come expecting belly dancers or anything silly like that (if you're in a persian restaurant with belly dancing, you're in a bad restaurant. It's there to distract you). The servers/waitresses are nice and you definitely get a family feel for the place. They were very accommodating with our little guy and made us feel welcome.
author: Baron C.

description:
Where there is a good kebab, there's Ranjani.

The husband and I stumbled across this restaurant while driving back from an appointment and man, when I see a Persian restaurant, I want to eat there. Doesn't matter what the quality, quantity or ambience is like. I will eat there.

Anar definitely surprised me. I lived in the East Bay for the longest and trust me, there's no shortage of good Persian food there. I obviously know my koobideh kebab, my joojeh kebab and my kashk-e-bademjan. And so do the chefs at Anar :)

There was no wait on the evening we walked in. What struck me was the ambiance, very clean and not over top the Middle Eastern-y, like a lot of places are in order to emphasize the type of cuisine. And yes, no belly dancers and all that jazz. I say, let the food speak for itself.

We ordered anar juice (pomegranate juice that tasted exceptionally fresh), one doodh (which is basically a salty buttermilk-y beverage), one koodibeh kebab plate with rice, one joojeh kebab plate with rice, one kashk-e-bademjan (eggplant dip with a yogurt base). Like, you cannot go wrong ordering any of these at a Persian restaurant. They also provided us with a bowl of lavash, to compliment the eggplant. The food didn't stand a chance. The koobideh was inhaled. Half the joojeh went home with me for lunch the next day, as the quantities served are substantial. And well, it didn't stand a chance the next day. The eggplant was inhaled. Suffice to say, the food here is awesome!

Service was extremely attentive & sweet. Food comes out relatively fast. And the price didn't burn a hole in our wallet. I'll be sure to come back. And bring friends & family along, because the food here is worth the raving it gets.
author: Ranjani S.

description: A must go place for all kinds of Persian dishes that tastes even better than a home made Iranian food :) super friendly staff and a cozy environment. I feel so welcomed and the staff help my experience more enjoyable. Highly recommended.
author: Farnaz K.

description:
I'm sad to say that we did not have a good experience here. The place is beautiful and was certainly a very nice environment to dine in, but that was about it. We had a large party and we tried to be very respectful, quiet, and organized when ordering. That said, this place is definitely not good at handling a lot of people, which is a shame because a lot of their appetizers and dishes are perfect for sharing. 

While the hostess who took our orders was friendly enough, the servers who brought the food to the table were quite brusque and had no idea what the dishes were and who they belonged to. Service was attentive when it came to refilling carafes, but pretty slow with everything else. We might have asked for the bill three times before it actually showed up. 

As for the food, I think it is severely overpriced. Entrees are mostly rice or bread but average $20 or more. I ordered the lamb chops, which were nearly $30. For that, I got 5 small pieces of meat on a large bed of very strong raw onions and a large piece of flat bread. I did not find it very palatable and was unsure what to do with the very large pile of onions. Other members of our party ordered various forms of kebab and meat + rice dishes, and I just feel like the huge platters are mostly covered in rice and nothing else. The meats I tried were not especially tender nor flavorful. In the end, I did not feel like I was getting my money's worth. I admit I am not too familiar with Persian cuisine, but I've eaten around enough to know this place didn't quite hit the mark with me. 

I could see how this could be a good date spot or ideal for an intimate dining experience. But unfortunately, I feel like the quality of food and service does not quite live up to the swankier vibe of this place so I will probably not come here again.
author: Carol C.

description: When I travel to San Francisco I always seek out a different Persian restaurant (4 so far). What a pleasant surprise Anar was! The Koobideh kabob is the best I have had in the Bay Area by far! The service was also fantastic thanks to their very personable servers.
author: Amir O.

description:
Four of us went to dinner there last Friday night.   The restaurant was only about 1/3 full.   
Although the food was good, we got little direction on what to order when we asked - we were not very familiar with Persian food - but it turned out OK.
It was the service that suffered.   The table next to ours, seated after us, finally got up and left before anyone got to them (a good 8 - 10 minutes).

Our entrees all arrived at different times, with 6 - 7 minutes between the first and the last.

Oh, and as of yet, they have no liquor license, just so you know.

There are so many good restaurants in this city, I probably won't go back to this one.
author: Whitney D.

description:
Somewhere along Harrison street you will find the newly opened Anar tucked into a row of unwelcoming industrial buildings and soulless houses. As soon as you step into the place there is a change of scenery. A family owned and operated place with high ceilings, walls painted in rich earth tones and your first taste of Persia when you notice the paintings and calligraphy on the walls and appropriately placed little clay pomegranates (Anars) here and there. 

We arrived there in the afternoon for Persian tea and nibbled on some desserts which I will describe for you. First, was Shole Zard or saffron rice pudding, a heavenly fusion of rice pudding and saffron with an underscoring of butter, rosewater and traces of cinnamon and silvered almonds on top. It was quiet nice with the right color, texture and sweetness. Then we had Shir Berenj which is the less sweet simple version of Persian rice pudding and a much wiser choice for people like me who have to watch their high blood sugar. There was also Baklava that I did not try but looked fresh and fluffy. 

We had those with Persian tea which brewing a perfect one is a labor in itself. Tea was served in visually appealing traditional transparent glass cups called Estekaan which is a Russian word in case you were wondering. Along with the tea you get two pieces of dates and a small branch of fresh mint, a nice touch that adds to the flavor of the tea. Anar's tea isn't exactly what you can taste in a Persian tea-house in Baazaar or your grandma's place but close enough and far superior to the over brewed mediocre hot drink most places sell to you as tea!  

Staff was very nice and friendly and two young girls that checked on us a few times to make sure we have everything and a charming older gentleman who I believe was the owner and personally welcomed us and served our first round of tea. 

A glance at the food menu shows choices for the main course are adequate with couple items that invoked pleasant memories of back home. Main courses including Kababs and meat options are very reasonably priced compared to restaurants in the vicinity or the other 3 Persian restaurants in the city. 

I look forward to going back to Anar for the full experience and I think the place with its roomy high ceiling can enjoy a far richer and more rustic decor to complement the beautiful paintings and wall calligraphy. Perhaps, the whole place is even more enticing at night than it is in daytime complete with dim light of its exposed filament light bulbs and Persian music playing in the background all inviting you to indulge in rustic and flavorful Persian kababs and stews. 

If you go there, enjoy your time and Nooshe-Jaan.
author: Kaveh G.

description: A very pleasant dining experience with friendly service and a solid menu.  We got dolmehs, hummus, baghali polo, and gheymeh bademjan (sorry if my spelling is off).  The dolmehs and baghali polo were really good; the hummus and gheymeh bademjan were just OK.  None of us knew anything about Persian food, so I would urge you to listen to reviewers who are more experienced.  My rating is actually 3 1/2 stars, but you can't give 1/2 stars.  People around us were eating a lot of different delicious-looking dishes, so there is a good possibility that this rating will improve upon my next visit. Definitely worth a try.
author: JJ M.

description:
The food was good and tasty, but the service was totally unprofessional. The servers and the chef were very nice, but I guess the servers simply didn't know what service meant: Enough silverware was not provided, enough napkins were not provided, enough drinking glasses were not provided, and even when they returned the bill to us for signing, no pen was provided! Some of the food came lukewarm too.

Most of these were fixed when we asked (the drinking glass didn't ever appear), but after occasional delays. The point is we shouldn't even have asked for such basics!

The food was actually nice and felt like home cooking (which is a great thing for a Persian restaurant). The Loobia Polo tasted nice and Ash-e Laboo was a pleasant surprise. The Mirza Ghasemi tasted OK, but it wasn't authentic at all. More like a mixed eggplant omelet than real Mirza Ghasemi. The Doogh and the Salad Shirazi were nice.

The atmosphere was casual, which was desirable for our purpose.

Two stars for the excruciating lack of service.
author: Roozbeh P.

description:
I have been eating Persian food since I was a child and on three continents: home-made and restaurants. This is the BEST Persian food in SF right now, PERIOD!
We ordered: lubia polo, koubideh, Tahdig, chicken kebab, Mirza Ghazemi, Panir Sabzi, Shole Zard, Tahdig. It is outstanding. I peaked in the kitchen and no wonder: it is family run. The lady in the family is the chef. God bless her cooking. Order to go or sit down. This food makes you happy. When was the last time food made you happy?
author: armand d.

description:
We need more Persian restaurants in San Francisco, but I also want the food to be worthy of many future visits. I have mixed feelings about Anar Restaurant, as some of the Persian home-style food was really good like the spinach yogurt (mast-o esfenaj), but the chicken (joojeh) kabob was a little dry. 

The menu is small, with very few vegetarian options. I mentioned to the young waitress about the lack of vegetarian main dish options and she reacted as if she had never heard of this being an issue, which is ridiculous since we are in San Francisco. She also did not offer any substitutions for the vegetarian diner. The day we came to Anar there was nothing unusual about the menu offerings, it's mostly the same dishes as the other Persian restaurants in San Francisco including; Lavash, Alborz and Maykadeh but with less menu choices. It was unclear if their menu changes periodically?

I ordered tea, but only given one 1/2 size sugar cube. My dining partner ordered bread, only a very small amount of bread given with one butter. It felt like everything was being measured, cutting corners and considering price over dining comfort.

Our waitress is not formally trained in waiting tables, as it was made obvious that she is related to someone that works/owns the business. This is really sweet that it is a family business, but it also means that they are not professional. The decor is homey, looks like someone in the family tried to help decorate. Hopefully they will find their footing over time and iron out some of the issues. 

gluten notes: 
Persian food is generally gluten-free friendly, however with the lesser options on the menu it is limiting. Avoid all things lavash or sangak.
author: Shannon Z.

description: The best fish and rice for Persian New Year. Five star food . Five star food. The best restaurant for truly authentic Persian food in San Francisco. The service is excellent.
author: Siroos H.

description:
I didn't really enjoy my experience eating here, although some of it wasn't their fault. I felt super uncomfortable with all the homeless people on the street where I parked (right around the corner). The street the restaurant is on was dirty and it seems to be a bad neighborhood. I felt unsafe being there. The inside was fine though. The staff was friendly and attentive. 

I've been to Persian places before where I live in Sacramento, and another establishment here in SF, and thought the food was good, however, that wasn't my experience here. I just wanted a simple beef koobideh, but they only had lamb. So I tried another dish and had some hummus. They were both ok, but I was left unsatisfied. I also tried a dessert, which is similar to kheer, an Indian dessert, but for some reason the Persian version tasted like soap. It is not my intention to be mean, I'm just giving my honest opinion. But what do I know? I'm American and have no idea what authentic Persian food should taste like. Although, I dined with my Persian friend, and he thought the food was just "ok" as well. My rating represents his experience, since he's Persian and knows what to compare it to, otherwise in all honesty, I would've rated it 2 stars. I feel bad about saying that, because the staff was so nice, but we're here on Yelp to be honest....not polite, right? By the way, I don't even want to know what that hose was for in the bathroom, lol.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I've had the pleasure of dining here on a couple of occasions; both times were truly exceptional. Bonus points for unsuspecting vegetarians as lots of their menu items fall into this category. 
The Kashk-e Badenjam (seasoned roasted eggplant, garnished with sun dried yogurt, sauteed onion, roasted garlic, mint flakes & saffron) was one of my favorite dishes.

Additionally, don't overlook the Fesenjan or the Mast o Bademjan.

This place is definitely an up-and-coming local favorite.
author: Liz W.

description:
Part of me wanted to review this restaurant a little better, but between the service, prices, and food it was hard to give above a 2. 

The service: The wait staff was very nice, but I did not expect to wait a little over an hour to receive my dish. If the restaurant was crowded then it would be understandable but for 3 tables being occupied (total of 6 people) an hour is a bit excessive to wait for two dishes. 

Price: Compared to other persian restaurants in their prices were a bit higher, and unlike many other restaurants I have been to when you do a mix and match it is expected to have a slight increase in price. But I was charged double for a mix and match. It would have been cheaper to buy two meals than to have bought the single meal. 

Food: The Kabob slightly better than Maykadeh, but I would choose Lavash over Anar. I would say their dishes are a bit healthier in the sense that the rice isn't saturated with butter and oil, and the meat is done well. Their Kabob wasn't charred as I have seen at other places. 

Overall, I expected Anar to be better than the rest being that it is a new place. Between the really slow service, outrageous price, and the ok food I would recommend visiting another place.
author: Sasan J.

description:
LITERARY my WORST experience in a restaurant ever. Haven't ever felt this much humiliated and disrespected by a waitress. The restaurant is well decorated, the food was descent. ( although it came 1 hour and half late) . The restaurant has the capacity of 50 something people and only one EXTREMELY RUDE waitress. No wonder why the customer service was extremely flawed , when the restaurant got half occupied. Instead of apologizing for the delay and "CHANGING our orders without even asking", the waitress started arguing in a loud tone of voice and said something about us being so many people!!!! 
I Know its hard opening a restaurant without any experience in "SERVING" customers. But that could be easily fixed with some training or even hiring experienced waiters (that are familiar with the very basic customer service rules).
author: Niki N.

description:
i always hate writing negative reviews or even reviews that don't rave about the place... but i do it from time to time, if it's warranted.

1. you always want to be honest.  
it's like interviewing a candidate for work. you can't lie about the place being awesome, if it isn't.  because if s/he accepts the job and the work conditions are horrible, you're stuck working the person and they no longer trust you.

2. you hope your review helps "better" the place, no one likes to see a business fail

shortly after i wrote my review, the manager at anar sent me a message thanking me for my review and noted they'd take my feedback into consideration.  makes me happy that my #2 reason was a (hopefully) a success!  with that said, i will give anar a second chance!  good + kind mgmt is always appreciated.

happy eating!
author: Tina F.

description:
First things first, the rice is REAL good - there are definitely real Iranians cooking in the back! 

Second, yes the service is slow and the two beautiful young persian ladies serving are definitely still learning their way around the restaurant ... but we weren't at all bothered by it. You can tell they have a stake in the restaurant and are trying their best. 

Salad Shirazi - not the best... too much olive oil
Mast-o-Khiar - delicious
Dough - home made - definitely should order this here
Koobideh - delicious
Bargh - lacked salt... but with a little bit added + sumac it was great
Zereshk Polo - winner winner chicken dinner!!! 
Tahdig - not on the menu, they offer it for free when they have it - we had to ask twice, and I am happy we did - because they gave it to us and it was delicious and fresh from the bottom of the dig (pot) !

All in all, this place is family run and barely been open one month. I found all the dishes we tried to be really good and better than most places that have been in business for years. 

I am looking forward to coming back here and trying out their other dishes!
author: Shanna N.

description:
I ate here with a friend; he is from Israel and I grew up in Iran. I got the baghali polo (fava beans, bill and rice) and he got the joojeh kebab (chicken kebab). Both were excellent. The polo was great and my pal's chicken was spot on! The dolma were delicate and beautiful. It was like being back in Shiraz. 

Suggestions: I wish that they would add some more traditional khoreshes (stews) and was disappointed that tadig (buttery rice crust) was not on the menu. Please, please add albaloo polo (cherry polo)! And better feta - it was too mild. I would prostrate myself for real sangak. There were some items that rotated on the menu, but the menu didn't note which days that they were served; perhaps have a regular posted daily special, so that folks could come on the day that their favorite food was being cooked.

This is genuine Persian cooking! The joint is run by a Persian family; mom does all the cooking, dad manages the restaurant, and I believe the daughters are the waitresses. The food came out quickly. The daughters need some practice waitressing. They were pleasant, but absentminded. The music was and atmosphere was soothing. 

I am grateful that they opened. will return to Anar and eat my way through the menu!
author: Avery C.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times and always got great service and delicious food.
Last night we went with a big group of friends. They managed our table with ease. The appetizers and food came quickly and yummy as always.
The staff are very nice & polite and do their best to take care of your party.
My favorite Iranian restaurant in SF, highly recommend.
author: Haleh H.

description: Totally cheap on the food delivery. $6 hummus was put into a dressing-sized container. $7 salads were put into a container that was a 1/2 pint in size, or even less. NO lavash bread or any other type of bread given with the dipping sauces. Dinner ended up being $54 for 2 tiny salads, 1 small side of hummus, yogurt and one stew. Very small quantities for the associated price!
author: Farrah L.

description: Great persian food. The food is delicious and amzing friendly environment - if you havent been there yet, then you are missing on a great quality Persian cuisine. Go NOW !!
author: Delbar S.

description: Fantastic service. Really delicious food. There were six of us and we tried different Kabobs, we all loved them all.
author: Mostafa M.

description:
7/13/14 does not seem like a good day for these guys, lots of 1 star reviews.

Oh well, my experience (on the same day) was pretty good. Checked out the place with some friends on a Sunday afternoon for some tea and "shirini". The servers seemed a bit shaken over some tense interaction with guests from another table, but they hid it well and continued with great service on our end. We were there for about an hour and had some tea and sweets. I cannot rate the food since I did not have any but I will definitely come back to try the main courses. Our group tried "Shole Zard", "Fereni" & "Baklava" and all were good. We spent a pleasant evening and the place felt homey. Will follow up later when I try the kababs!
author: Tara H.

description: Soo delicious!! I love getting their barg kabob. Meat is tender and their rice is light and fluffy. Hummus is really good as well! Charming restaurant and hospitable staff!
author: Jennifer G.

description:
I am persian and live somewhere there are no stores or restaurant that cater to our community...and my girlfriend is American so , at home I only make kabob, coming to anar was a treat to me! The food was as khanehgi (home cooked) as it gets, I had lubya pollo and mahicheh which was tops. Put away every bite. As well as every drop of my kashk eh bademjaan ...it was amazing. My girlfriend had her joojeh kabob , of course , And was happy. 

I may have well have been back in Abadan!
author: Jerry G.

description:
GREAT GREAT Persian food. Tastes homemade like my mothers food. EVERYTHING WAS EXCELLENT. 
I'm here visiting and so far have tried 3 other Persian food places in the Bay Area and this is at the top of my list now. 
The stews, kabobs, fish and rice were excellent. The tadig fried rice was delicious. 
Small family run place. The girls are very hospitable and inviting. 
Also The food was light- not too oily. I felt good. 
The services was personal and quick. 
Highly recommended. 
Thanks.
author: John A.

description:
Good food. Great atmosphere.

Love the staff for sure as they are fun to talk to and funny.
author: Adam S.

description:
The food at Anar just gets better and better every time I visit.
Tonight we had the Kashke bademjan, Sabzi with noon-o-panir, kabab soltani, and the special of the night, lamb tongues with baghali polo. Everthing was absolutely fantastic, especially my favorite the lamb tongues.
They also have recently obtained a liquor licence and have a nice selection of wine and beer.  This may be the best Persian restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Martin V.

description:
Best Persian food I've had in the city! 

Very authentic and generous portion. The koobideh is absolutely delicious. Service is friendly. 

Location is not the best in SOMA but it's near my place, and would be worth making a trip even if it wasn't.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
Nice local spot but could uou some service improvements.  You can tell it's a family run spot though. The complementary app. Is a Ritz cracker type cracker, with a cucumber slices and a small side of a bland but good feta type cheese. There's and "interesting" smell when you enter but it could be the new paint or furniture. 

The staff is very warm and courteous but not everyone speaks fluent English,  so there were times I was not sure my order was being taken correctly. 

So ill be honest,  I was expecting Mediterranean food. This is not your typical med spot. Feta was not what im familiar with but it was good. Just very light flavors in most the samplers.  Chicken was good and the various apps were unique. 
Very fresh and lots of food for the price. 

Ill for su do a second round soon .
author: Sharon S.

description:
Awesome food and awesome customer service. My former business partner is Iranian and I've been exposed to really good home cooking and been to excellent persian restaurants mainly in so cal. I'd have to say this place is a gem. 

We ordered the Koobideh and joojeh chicken which was tasty and juicy!

The smoked eggplant was AMAZING!! You must get it!

The wait staff are 2 sisters who are very friendly and accommodating. Take a look at the decor which one of the sisters painted! Beautiful!

This is a great moms and pops shop that will not disappoint 

I live right across the street and will be back when ever I want to get my persian fix!
author: Lyle D.

description:
This place opened up not too long ago, and since there's always so many places to eat at in SF, I try not to have repeats unless the place is really good. I had such a great experience here that I'll definitely be back!

Straight from the source: This place is a family-owned business. The waitresses are sisters and the chefs are a dad and his son-in-law. They came to the US a year ago and opened up a restaurant having owned one in Iran. To top it off, the paintings on the wall were painted by one of the sisters. They were all so friendly, modest and personable. I LOVE IT! 

The food was incredible. I got the chicken kabobs and my boyfriend got the koobideh kabobs. His was off the hook! Mine was also tasty, but I'll get the koobideh for sure next time. Each plate came with rice and grilled tomatoes. 

My experience was made even better because an older gentleman who sat next to us gave us the scoop on Persian cuisine. "Anar is pomegranate in Farsi, and they are the symbol of love." That's why you'll see pomegranate used as decor. He told us to try to tea next time, because it was delicious.

Next time I'm craving Persian, you know where I'll be.
author: Mimi V.

description:
Went with a few work friends. The food was fantastic. The service was super awesome. The environment was cozy. They gave us free drinks and desserts to try out. 
Stuff we tried includes: 
Salmon with rice which I would rate highly.
Kobiedeh which my friend absolutely loved. The chicken was succulent and the sauce it came with was finger licking good. The capsicum dolmeh looked and tasted fantastic. 
I have a bit of a sweet tooth and I just completely loved the rice pudding.
I would go again probably many times. :)
author: Sabika N.

description:
This is a great restaurant.  I've tried Persian food many times and liked it, but never been blown away.  This place definitely changed my mind.  Not only was the food great, but the prices were totally reasonable.  That's not something you come to expect living in San Francisco.  I went on a Thursday evening for dinner and the place was pretty empty....hopefully it was just an off-night because this restaurant deserves more.

The only suggestion I have would be to add better (not necessarily more) beer to the menu.  When the best choice is Pacifico, we've got a problem.
author: Erik L.

description:
Great Iranian food, I went there with my family and my father and I had the koobideh. They gave large portions and it was extremely delicious. The meat was very tender and moist. 

My mother had the akhtar morg, which was amazing. This type of chicken is served frequently in shomal (northern part of Iran) and it was amazing, especially the sauce that came with it. 

Overall it was an excellent experience with very friendly service. I would definitely go here again and bring my friends too.
author: Nima F.

description: Nice Persian food. The kabob was awesome and well cooked. Great service and nice staff. We went with friends and all of enjoy the food
author: Diamond J.

description:
This was my first time trying Persian food...and it was absolutely delicious. 

We started off with the Dolmeh (which is a grape leaf filled with beef, rice, peas and other herbs) and some Adasi (lentil soup). The Dolmeh had a really tangy exterior, which contrasted well with its meaty mixed inside. I was basically ready to cancel my main course and ask for 3 or 4 more orders of it.

My friend and I shared two dishes - the Kabab Koobideh and the Kabab Shishlik. The Koobideh skewers were huge and cooked to perfection, and the Shishlik (Lamb Chops) had this amazing smoked lamb flavor. They were each served with rice and a huge roasted tomato. 

Maybe the best part of the entire meal were the spices and sauce. Anar has some really mild pepper flakes that go well with skewers, and a special "Spicy Pomegranate infused sauce" which is kind of like tabasco with fruit. Doesn't sound like it would work...but it works.

Topping this all off were two really friendly servers (I think sisters or family) and some great interior decor. I'll be back soon!
author: Dennis R.

description:
Loved Anar.

Lets start off with the most important factor, which is the food. It was fantastic. As many reviewers have said, it tasted homemade which is a refreshing change from most Persian restaurants. We ordered a few different items to share, this is not typical in a Persian restaurant but we wanted to taste a number of things so we ordered family style.

For starters we ordered the Mirza Ghasemi and the soup - the MG was so good that one member of our party was considering ordering a few more plates and having it as his entree. I didnt have the soup but others said it was great. We then ordered a Koobideh/Joojeh combo, a Fesenjan and the Ghalyee Kadu as our main dishes. All items were delicious. The Koobideh was very well made and had the perfect texture/flavor. The Joojeh was pretty good as well but not as good as the Koobideh. The khoreshts were both pretty good but the other item, often neglected in reviews, that was great was the rice. The grains were large, fluffy, and not too moist/dry.  

As for the decor and ambiance I'd say it was pretty nice for a neighborhood restaurants. Perhaps the lights could be dimmed ever so slightly to create a warmer, more intimate mood.

Will definitely be back - nice to see a new contender in the market!
author: Farid H.

description: Great restaurant! It was about a mile trek from my hotel and it was worth every step. The ambiance was nice and cozy, the staff was polite and attentive, and the food was amazing! I shared the koobideh with a buddy and we both left super full. The koobideh was the juiciest I have had, ever! It was a little oversalted but undersalting food is more of a crime to me so I let it pass. My friend thought the rice was greasy and/or watery but I didn't get that impression. Would come back again!
author: Terri C.

description: So amazing!  They are very authentic, right down to offering fessejen.  LOVE it!!
author: Amanda C.

description:
The service is phenomenal and the food is even better.

I got the Jojeh Kabob and it's awesome! You have the choice of starch (I got the lavash bread) as well as heaping portions of meat and grilled veggies.

The entire combo was phenomenal and Anar is a gem in our neighborhood.
author: Ashwin M.

description: Anar is wonderful! I'm vegan and there were a couple different options for me which is always nice. I went with the veggie kebab and it was delicious. My carnivore boyfriend had the lamb stew and loved it as well. We split the hummus appetizer and each had a glass of wine and still only paid about $60. The decor is warm and inviting and the staff is very friendly. We will definitely be back!
author: Hannah Z.

description: I had their kebob that mixes beef and lamb. It was pretty tasty, however I do think it needs a sauce or something to dip it in. Overall this place was pretty tasty, with big portions, but I wasn't blown away and it's not that cheap.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Ordered food from here and it took over 2 hours to arrive.  I called the location and the restaurant was completely clueless and took no responsibility at all.  Very poor customer service.  Don't order from here.  Horrible experience.

UPDATE: Your response is just more excuse making.  YOU ARE RESPONSIBLE for your food and as I pointed out in my first post, when I called you washed your hands of any responsibility and now you have done it again.  Customer reviews are the ONLY power we consumers have to expose bad business performance and customer service.  You actually list your are going to make it up to me??  How so??  Too late for that.  As of 10:30pm still no food.  So that's 2 hours and 35 minutes if you are keeping count.  And I don't appreciate you writing a post that attempts to make it seem you guys did nothing wrong!

Once again, I urge people to stay clear of this restaurant and give their money and patronage to businesses who value their customers instead of making excuses for poor service like ANAR.

The many poor reviews you have received should have warned me to STAY AWAY.
author: Ramon E.

description:
One of the best persian places around. 

Service was awesome. I loved the Joojeh kabob. Rice was great too. My friend had koobideh, and she loved it. This is going to be my regular eat.
author: Priyank C.

description:
We live right across the street @950.  This is a first time we decided to visit this place since it was opened.  Seven months ago.  

We've seen this place changed hats for the past ten years.  Sandwich place (most successful), then Peruvian (short-term), now Persian.  Somehow we do now predict them a bright future either.  Not a good foot traffic.  Prices are pretty high.  Closing times early.  And too upscale for this hood.   

Food - nod bad, not fantastic either.  A-OK as indicated.
author: Alex R.

description:
I am glad a good Persian restaurant has opened in our neighborhood. I have had chicken kebab, koobideh, gheymeh, and mirza ghasemi and I liked all of them. The service is very attentive and friendly. I usually customize my orders a lot but they were every nice about it. They just opened so I guess they are still learning a few things on the job but you always feel welcome. 
Tip: Ask for Sangak bread with your kebab
author: Behnam R.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  Seriously, I was so excited.  Either I'm in the Twilight Zone or something just went terribly wrong when I was there.  I ordered the chicken kebab plate and a side of pita bread and a "freshly squeezed" lemonade. 

Pros: Best part, the roasted tomato and the rice.  

Cons: Everything else!  Seriously, gross.  What are people reviewing? Definitely not anything I ordered.  The chicken tasted like it was soaked in salt for days.  It came with a salad drowned in dressing, awful.  Pita bread came in a zip lock bag, tasted as if it was a couple days old. 

Finally: powdered lemonade passed off as fresh!  I asked the young lady who helped me with my order if the lemonade was made in house, fresh. She replied yes. I get it home and it tasted like lemon popsicle water!  I call them because I can't eat aspartame and was really upset, not that i wasted my time looking for decent food there, but because it's ridiculous that someone would lie about that. I call and the gentleman was very nice and explained they use powdered lemonade (after a few rounds of questioning).  I will admit the girl was very nice when she blatantly told me they make it fresh.  Who lies about that? I'm hoping she didn't understand because that is lame!

I won't be back...too bad I wanted to like this place.  I would have to starve myself for a couple weeks to enjoy this place.  Wish I would've given the 25 bucks to the homeless guy off the freeway exit, would've been better used that way. Guess I will be back at my favorite Mediterranean place tomorrow and try to forget the experience.
author: Cia C.

description:
Very good Kobideh (Ground beef bbq )
Must to try Mast_Bademjan (eggplant mixed yogurt)
Very nice service
author: Amir K.

description: Perfect Persian food in SF, I live in LA and in my city we have a lot of good Persian food but this place served top rated Persian food and I recomend this restaurant for Persian food
author: Ali S.

description:
Amazing Quality Food and extremely reasonable prices!! 
Best kabob I've had in a while at a restaurant (especially their koobideh). Their rice dishes and appetizers are awesome too. Also try the Bagheli polo and Lamb and the Eggplant Tomato appetizer (Mirza ghasemi). Have had the saffron rice pudding too, which was amazing.
I'm Persian, and I've brought so many non-persians here and they all Love It and think it's such great quality and the prices are insanely affordable. The owners are sweet and super accommodating, they keep the restaurant open late if you are eating or come late and are super friendly.

Even though it's a little out of the way, there is always easy parking and the food more than makes up for it. You have to try them out!

for the Persians, best koobideh in the SF area I've tried so far. Definitely get those on your first visit!
author: Pegah E.

description:
Great food. Very friendly staff . Easy parking
Excellent Desert 
Try Tea with free refill
author: Alireza K.

description:
Everything on the menu is great.  The pomegranate soup is excellent and a great starter.  The different meat dishes are all wonderful.  It's now a staple in our SOMA restaurant rotation.

fyi - it's halal
author: Aamir V.

description:
Great food , great price , very attentive to the clients 

It's a great family run restaurant , just as good as mamas cooking 

Recommend getting the lamb shank and the lamb kebab
author: Emine B.

description:
Very clean and great decor and ambience. Service was a little slower then accepted for the reason that there were only two girls working here as servers. I think they are sisters and this is a family business. The koobideh (beef) kabob has lamb mixed in with the beef- usually Persian restaurants don't do this so if you don't like lamb and really love koobiedeh kabob then your out of luck. I feel great about this restaurant in general though and will probably be coming back. Tried the chicken kabob, ghameh(eggplant & beef stew) and Persian ice cream! They were all great except of the beef/lamb kabob. But that's just me. I should have read the menu more clearly to be honest.  

Also this is one of the cleanest restrooms I have ever used in a restaurant! Superb haha
author: Behzod T.

description:
Caution: Call ahead before you go.

The first time I tried to order food to-go, they would not take my order because they were too busy.  Tonight, they are not taking any dinners or to-go orders because of a private party.
author: Randy O.

description:
I really enjoyed a fabulous lunch at Anar.  I went with my Persian friend, who was not familiar with this new restaurant. I read about Anar in a recent SF Weekly review and I've eaten at Lavosh in the past and living in SOMA - I wanted to check this place out.   My pal is originally from Tehran and he loved Anar!

The food, service and ambience at Anar are excellent.   We ordered a bunch of stuff - everything was fantastic.  I loved the yogurt stuff, the eggplant stuff, the kebabs, the lamb, the grill Cornish hen, the pomegranate sauce,  etc.   Amazing flavors and super high quality food.  This is a great restaurant for a casual lunch or dinner.  Do yourself a favor and check out Anar!

Also, there is a great wine store next door that I never knew was there!  I bought a bottle of the Clase Azul Blanco tequila - my absolute favorite blanco, but that is another story...
author: Ron K.

description: Excellent koobideh (lamb) kabab! Especially for the price and size of the dish. The restaurant is clean and open. The service was great and I would make this my go-to spot for Persian food. My Persian father-in-law approves, which says a lot. Great place!
author: Joyce P.

description:
Went here with my girlfriend for dinner. Location is easy to find and plenty of parking. Walking from Caltrain to the restaurant though was a bit sketchy. At night I don't think it's the safest area to walk around. 
The place itself is very nice. We went there last Thursday, and it was not crowded at all. Didn't need reservation. The waitress is a nice lady but a little shy. Didn't really explain the menu or specials if they had any. Luckily we are both Persians and knew what we wanted. 
The service was fast. Good arrived warm quickly. We shared a ghormeh sabzi and tahdig dish for appetizer. The ghormeh sabzi was very flavorful, aromatic and well prepared. I think the sabzi used was actually fresh. We also shared a dish of bakhtiari which is half barg and half joojeh. Very tender meat and well done rice. I wasn't a huge fan of the marinade used for barg. I like to taste the meat. The marinade was too safarroni for my taste. The rice was good amount of buttery. 
We also got two glasses of home made doogh which was good. Wish they had used fresh mint in it but it was still good. Overall really nice place. Good staff. Good food. I recommend it.
author: Anahita Y.

description: Fabulous! My first time eating Persian food and I loved it! We loved the crispy rice appetizer and the shallot yogurt sauce. The pomegranate chicken was excellent. We will be back!
author: Ian And Am C.

description:
This is in response to Jennifer R who was a diner at Anar tonight. I was sitting across from this table and I felt very sorry for the abuse that the poor waitress had to put up with. I heard everything and saw everything. She threatened poor yelp review. she asked the man in her party not to leave a tip. The two other ladies and the man were embarrassed by her. They also took home leftovers that were not good.  Anar is a great Persian restaurant. Fresh food and great service. Lucky to have them in the city. 
Nothing shady about soma. Don't abuse your wait staff. Grow up. I highly recommend Anar.
author: Farid Y.

description: Great service, recommended the special a bone in lamb shank. It was so tender it pulled apart just by looking at it. Had stuffed grape leaves, and beet soup to start, great dishes and flavor from both. The shank finished me off as did a bite of my partners chicken kabob. Amazing.
author: John H.

description:
Do not eat at this place especially if you are inviting a foreigner or your girlfriend to try Persian cuisine. You will regret it as I did. So sad that I have to write a negative review for a Persian restaurant but I feel like others have to know so they do not get embarrassed in front of their guests. 

First of all, they do not serve authentic Persian food and it takes them forever to bring it, even if there is not a lot of people there. The problem is that the staff there are very mean. When a family behind us, asked why they are so slow in serving she gave her a 5 minute lecture that a restaurant cannot serve them the food the moment they come in and that they only have one stove. This is so mean, you have to first apologize! and then explain why. I have been to many restaurants and the ones that do not have a fast service at least provide their customers with some appetizer till their food is ready. A popular Persian appetizer is fresh vegetable, with cheese and nan (bread). That costs a restaurant nothing to serve its customers and almost all Persian restaurants that I have been to do it complimentary. That is NOT the case here, it will cost you 8 dollars to order it!! You have to just sip water for thirty minutes till they bring your food.

We were there for dinner and for the main order you have choices between kabob and stew. They give you an option when you order Kabob (lamb) or Joojeh (chicken). You can either order rice and bread or salad and bread. Ordering Kabob and bread is a popular choice. I was excited about the salad as well, since it is usually made very tasty in Persian restaurants and dressed beautifully. So I ordered that and after waiting for about 30 minutes the food was served. 

I could not be more disappointed. The salad was just a bunch of lettuce that was mixed with Balsamic vinegar. No effort was made to make anything look good at all.  What is surprising is that there is no Balsamic vinegar in Persian Cuisine. You can not even find it in Iran. None of my guests liked the salad. It is a real pitty that they do not serve the real persian Salad. I was really disappointed and asked to talk to the manager to give her some suggestion as a good will.
